Text: 'Some time ago, a website pointed out the dangers of public check-ins, which are online announcements of where you are. The website's message was clear: while you might think you are simply saying, "Hey, I’m at this place," you are also revealing your location to many people, not all of whom you may want to meet. This highlights a growing awareness that there can be negative aspects to the constant sharing enabled by the internet. The internet offers many exciting opportunities to share our lives with a global audience, which can lead to wealth and fame. However, we often dive into this digital world, sharing personal stories and photos, only to realize later that it can be overwhelming and risky.

This situation may seem discouraging, but there is hope. The future has been mapped out for us by early internet pioneers. In the beginning, these pioneers explored the internet and identified its dangers. They faced job losses, changes in friendships, and the challenges of fame long before social media existed. These early bloggers have experienced what many of us are now facing. It is important to learn from their experiences, as those who do not learn from history are likely to repeat it.

In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the World Wide Web, which was mostly used by graduate students, scientists, and a few young people like him. The web was created at CERN, a physics lab in Switzerland, to help researchers share their work. Hall saw a different opportunity: to share his life. He created a complex online autobiography filled with personal stories, photos, and art. In January 1996, he began a daily blog, attracting many readers who were fascinated by his bold use of this new medium. Hall's approach was straightforward: anyone who crossed his path could be featured on his site, and no topic was off-limits. While some may see this as exhibitionism, there was also a unique beauty to his work that many would consider art.

However, one day, visitors to Hall’s site found his homepage replaced by a single, emotional video titled Dark Night. In it, he shared that he had fallen deeply in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was told, "either the blog goes, or I do." Hall felt that sharing his life online made people distrust him. The blog was removed, but the issue remains. Sharing online can be wonderful, but if you think that sharing your life will make people want to be around you, you may be disappointed.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a young web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. Sometimes, she wrote about her job at a software company. One day, an anonymous coworker sent the link to her blog to all the vice presidents at her company, including some she had criticized, which led to her losing her job. Researchers studying online behavior have a term for this: the "online distribution effect," which describes the feeling that we can say things online that we would never say in person. However, the internet is not a separate reality where we can speak freely without consequences. Our online lives are connected to our real lives, and ignoring this can lead to serious mistakes.

Armstrong's story had a happy ending. Although she was upset and stopped blogging for a few months, she eventually got married and restarted her blog, focusing on her new family. Today, she is a well-known "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. Once a symbol of the risks of online sharing, she has become skilled at managing her self-revelation. Armstrong's experience teaches us an important lesson: while the internet allows us to say anything, that doesn’t mean we should.'

Text: 'Some scientists recently started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called What the Bleep Do We Know? This film mixes documentary and drama to suggest that there is much we do not understand about our universe. How can any scientist disagree with that? While scientists can sometimes be arrogant, even the most confident physicist would not claim to know everything about the cosmos. However, some scientists felt it was necessary to publicly warn against the film, using strong language like ‘atrocious’ and ‘very dangerous’. This made the film seem like a must-see. 

At first, I didn’t understand the fuss. Various scientists made harmless statements about how new discoveries were showing the universe to be stranger than expected. It was only when the film discussed some of these discoveries that I began to see the reason for the excitement—discoveries like the idea that water molecules can be influenced by thoughts. I had heard before about a Japanese researcher who claimed that the shape of a water molecule could change based on the thoughts of people nearby. However, the film only provided pictures of ice crystals that looked beautiful after being spoken to positively and ugly after being exposed to negative emotions. Many people find this kind of evidence convincing because it is simple and can evoke positive feelings. But among scientists, the common reaction is skepticism. 

I understand their point. The idea that thoughts can affect water is fascinating and suggests new forces in the universe. However, we need solid proof that this effect is real. Beautiful pictures of crystals, while nice, are not enough. The real issue is that the film’s claims were not strange enough. Consider this: water molecules might have properties linked to a mysterious energy that seems to come from nowhere, which could be related to a force driving the universe's expansion. The evidence for this is not just pretty pictures; it comes from years of research in labs and observatories worldwide. 

In fact, discoveries are being made that confirm the film’s claim that the universe is stranger than we thought. Astronomers have discovered that the universe contains an unknown type of matter and is driven by a mysterious force called ‘dark energy’. Additionally, more down-to-earth discoveries are equally surprising. Neuroscientists have found that our awareness of events is delayed by about half a second, a delay we do not notice because our brains edit it out. Anthropologists believe they have found where modern humans originated and how they spread across the world. Some theorists even suggest links between life on Earth and the fundamental design of the universe. 

Despite what some may think, science is not close to being complete. In fact, we seem further from knowing everything than ever. It is clear that many natural phenomena cannot be understood as we once thought. The ideas of chaos and quantum uncertainty have shown that there are limits to our knowledge. This has led some of the world’s top theoretical physicists to work on a Theory of Everything, which aims to explain all the forces and particles in the universe with one equation. Overall, many of us believe that the universe can best be described in one word: incredible.'

Text: "In simple terms, I find writing novels challenging, while writing short stories is a joy. If writing novels is like planting a forest, then writing short stories is like planting a garden. Both processes complement each other, creating a landscape I cherish. The trees provide shade, and the wind rustles the leaves, which sometimes turn a bright gold. In the garden, flowers bloom, and colorful petals attract bees and butterflies, showing the gentle change of seasons. 

Since I began my career as a fiction writer, I have often alternated between writing novels and short stories. My routine is this: after finishing a novel, I want to write short stories; after completing a set of short stories, I feel ready to focus on a novel. I never write short stories while working on a novel, and I don’t write a novel while working on short stories. The two types of writing may engage different parts of the brain, and it takes time to switch from one to the other. 

I started my career with two short novels in 1975, and from 1984 to 1985, I began writing short stories. I knew little about writing short stories then, so it was challenging, but I found the experience memorable. I felt my fictional world expand, and readers seemed to enjoy this different side of me as a writer. One of my early works, ‘Breaking Waves’, was included in my first short-story collection, Tales from Abroad. This marked my beginning as a short-story writer.

One joy of writing short stories is that they don’t take long to finish. Generally, it takes me about a week to shape a short story (though revisions can take longer). It’s not the same total commitment required for the year or two it takes to write a novel. You enter a room, finish your work, and leave. For me, writing a novel can feel endless, and I sometimes wonder if I will make it through. So, writing short stories provides a necessary change of pace.

Another nice thing about short stories is that you can create a story from the smallest ideas—an idea, a word, an image, or anything. Often, it feels like jazz improvisation, with the story leading me where it wants to go. Plus, with short stories, you don’t have to worry about failing. If an idea doesn’t work out, you can simply accept it and move on. Even great writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver didn’t write a masterpiece every time. This thought comforts me. 

You can learn from your mistakes and use that knowledge in your next story. When I write novels, I try to learn from both the successes and failures I experience in writing short stories. In this way, short stories serve as a kind of experimental space for me as a novelist. It is hard to experiment the way I like within a novel, so without short stories, writing novels would be even more difficult.

My short stories are like soft shadows I have left in the world, faint footprints of my journey. I remember exactly where I placed each one and how I felt at that moment. Short stories are like guideposts to my heart, and it makes me happy as a writer to share these intimate feelings with my readers."

Text: 

Science, at its core, connects with philosophy, but it also has practical uses, like curing diseases. It has improved our lives but also posed threats. Science seeks to understand everything from tiny atoms to the vast universe, yet it often falls short. It influences poets, politicians, and thinkers, but its beauty is sometimes only seen by those who study it deeply. People often misunderstand its dangers, and its significance can be both overestimated and underestimated. The history of science is marked by constant change and conflict. Established ideas are frequently challenged or replaced, similar to how new music styles are initially mocked before becoming popular. Scientists can be competitive, and jealousy and anger are common emotions in their field. 

This book will explore scientific ideas that have transformed not just science but also human thought. While science has practical benefits, we will focus on its concepts and their beauty, while also recognizing the limitations of human understanding. Science is always evolving, with new discoveries often disproving previous explanations. Most of the time, these changes do not disrupt society, but sometimes they challenge our established beliefs. For example, in the 17th century, science introduced the idea of a mechanical universe, but by the 20th century, physics began to question this view, leading to complex ideas about how we interact with the universe.

Some people see the changing nature of scientific theories as a weakness, but these changes often improve our understanding and ability to predict natural events. For instance, Isaac Newton explained more than Aristotle, and Albert Einstein advanced our knowledge even further. Science may face setbacks, but it continues to progress. At the end of the 19th century, many physicists believed there was little left to discover, yet soon after, groundbreaking discoveries like radioactivity and quantum mechanics emerged.

Biology has also made significant advancements. Today, some claim we are close to a "theory of everything" that explains the universe's origins. However, science is not just an academic pursuit. Over the last two centuries, we have shifted from merely observing nature to influencing it, sometimes disrupting its balance without fully understanding the consequences. 

It is crucial for everyone, not just scientists, to engage with scientific advancements, as these developments will shape the future for generations to come. The implications of scientific progress can impact everything from government budgets to the health of future children and the overall future of life on Earth.

From around 2015, after many years of growth, major publishers began to notice that ebook sales had leveled off or even declined in some cases. This raised questions about the long-term future of ebooks in the publishing industry. One anonymous publishing executive recently admitted that the excitement around ebooks may have led to poor investments, causing his company to lose faith in the value of printed books. Despite the clear idea that digital and print books can coexist, the debate about whether ebooks will replace print books continues. Whether people are trying to predict or dismiss this idea, it remains a topic that sparks our imagination and intense discussion. 

Why is this idea so compelling? Why do we see the relationship between ebooks and print books as a conflict, even when evidence suggests otherwise? The answers to these questions extend beyond ebooks and reveal much about our mixed feelings of excitement and fear regarding innovation and change. In my research, I have explored how the notion of one medium 'killing' another often arises with new technologies. Even before digital technology, critics predicted the end of existing media. For example, after television was invented, many believed radio would disappear. However, radio adapted and found new audiences, such as people listening in cars or at work. 

The idea of books disappearing is not new either. As early as 1894, people speculated that the phonograph would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This pattern has repeated itself with movies, radio, television, hyperlinks, and smartphones, all of which were once thought to threaten print books as cultural sources. Some believed that the end of books would lead to cultural decline, while others exaggerated the benefits of ebooks in a digital future. 

The idea of the death of the book often arises during technological changes. This narrative reflects our hopes and fears about such changes. To understand why these feelings are so common, we must recognize that we form emotional connections with different media as they become part of our lives. Studies show that we can develop strong attachments to objects like books, televisions, and computers, even naming our cars or expressing frustration at our laptops. Therefore, when new technology, like e-readers, emerges, it not only signifies economic and social change but also forces us to rethink our relationship with something that has become essential to our daily lives. 

As technology evolves, we often yearn for what we once knew but no longer have. This longing is why industries arise around retro products and older technologies. For instance, the spread of the printing press in 15th-century Europe led people to seek original manuscripts. The transition from silent to sound movies in the 1920s created nostalgia for the earlier format. The same occurred with the shift from analog to digital photography and from vinyl records to CDs. Unsurprisingly, e-readers have sparked a renewed appreciation for the physical qualities of 'old' books, including their unique smell. 

This should reassure those who worry about the decline of print books. However, the idea of disappearing media will continue to be an engaging story about the transformative power of technology and our resistance to change. One way we cope with change is by using familiar narrative patterns, such as stories of tragedy and endings. The narrative of the death of the book is easy to remember and share, reflecting both our excitement for the future and our fear of losing parts of our familiar world—and ultimately, ourselves.

Text: "For a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30 every weekday morning. I brushed my teeth, made coffee, and wrote about how some of the greatest thinkers of the last four hundred years managed their time to do their best work. I focused on the everyday details of their lives—when they slept, ate, worked, and worried—to offer a new perspective on their personalities and careers. The French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, 'Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are.' I would say, 'Tell me what time you eat and if you take a nap afterward.' This book may seem superficial because it looks at the conditions of creative work rather than the work itself. However, it is also personal. The novelist John Cheever believed that even a business letter reveals something about the writer's inner self, which is true. 

My main concerns in this book reflect my own struggles: How can you do meaningful creative work while making a living? Is it better to focus entirely on one project or to work a little each day? When time is limited, do you have to give up things like sleep or a clean house, or can you learn to do more in less time? I do not claim to answer these questions definitively; some may not have clear answers and can only be resolved through personal compromises. However, I have provided examples of how many successful people have faced similar challenges. I wanted to show how big creative ideas can be broken down into small daily actions and how working habits can affect the work itself.

The title of the book is Daily Rituals, but I really focused on people's routines. Routines can seem ordinary and thoughtless, like being on autopilot. Yet, a good routine can help you use limited resources like time, willpower, and optimism effectively. A solid routine creates a path for your mental energy and helps manage your moods. The psychologist William James believed that putting part of your life on autopilot through good habits allows you to focus on more interesting activities. Ironically, he struggled with procrastination and could not stick to a regular schedule.

Interestingly, it was a moment of procrastination that inspired this book. One Sunday afternoon, while working at a small architecture magazine, I was supposed to write a story due the next day. Instead of working, I found myself tidying my workspace and making coffee. As a 'morning person,' I could focus well in the early hours but struggled after lunch. To feel better about this, I started looking online for information about other writers' schedules. I found many entertaining stories and thought it would be great to collect them, which led to the Daily Routines blog I started that day and now this book.

The blog was informal; I shared descriptions of people's routines from biographies, magazine articles, and obituaries. For the book, I have gathered a more extensive and well-researched collection while keeping the variety of voices that made the blog enjoyable. I have let my subjects speak for themselves through quotes from letters, diaries, and interviews. In some cases, I summarized their routines from secondary sources. I must acknowledge that this book would not have been possible without the research of many biographers, journalists, and scholars. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section, which I hope will guide further reading."

Text: 'Howard became a palaeontologist after a rise in interest rates when he was six years old. His father, a careful man with a big mortgage, said that their planned holiday to Spain was no longer possible. Instead, they rented a chalet on the English coast, and on a rainy August afternoon, Howard found an ammonite on the beach. He had always wanted to be a palaeontologist, and by the end of university, he knew what kind he wanted to be. He was interested in the very beginnings of life, rather than the more famous areas like dinosaurs. He studied small creatures found in grey rocks. As he finished his doctoral thesis, he wondered if he would get a job, especially in the institution he wanted. He was confident in his abilities but knew that deserving a job does not always guarantee getting one. When the Assistant Lectureship at Tavistock College in London opened, he applied, though he did not expect much.

On the day of Howard’s interview, the professor who was supposed to lead the panel had a fight with his wife. He left home upset, crashed his car into a gatepost, and ended up in the hospital. The interview went ahead without him, and the professor who replaced him was someone who disliked Howard’s former professor. This man managed to ensure that Howard got the job. Howard was surprised by this unexpected support and felt grateful until a colleague later explained the situation to him. He was a bit disappointed, wishing he could believe he was chosen for his skills and personality. However, what mattered most was that he had the job and could do the work he loved.

Howard often compared his orderly professional life, where he could plan and pursue scientific truth, with the chaos of personal life. Many people can affect your life, and sometimes a stranger can change everything, as Howard discovered when his briefcase, containing notes for a lecture, was stolen at an Underground station. Upset, Howard returned to college, called to explain, and postponed the lecture. He reported the theft and then went for a coffee. There, he met a colleague who was with a curator from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. This conversation led Howard to learn about a new collection of fossils that needed to be studied, which would be his biggest challenge and secure his future. Because of the theft, he quickly changed his plans. He decided not to go to a conference in Stockholm or take students on a field trip to Scotland. Instead, he would find a way to visit the museum in Nairobi.'

Charles Spence is willing to try almost any food. He mentions that he has ice cream made from bee larvae at home, which may look unusual but supposedly tastes "slightly nutty and floral." One of Spence's goals is to make eating insects more acceptable. As a Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University, he studies how our senses work together to shape our experience of taste. His research influences what we eat and drink, from large food companies to high-end restaurant menus.

Spence and his colleagues explore how various factors affect our taste experience, including who we eat with, how food is presented, and even the color and weight of plates and utensils. His book, *The Perfect Meal*, co-authored with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman, offers interesting insights about dining. For example, did you know that the first person to order in a restaurant tends to enjoy their meal more? Also, we eat about 35% more food when dining with one other person, and this increases to 75% more with three others.

Spence's lab in Oxford is quite simple, filled with basic equipment. He has soundproof booths and older audio-visual tools. By keeping costs low, he can collaborate with chefs who may not have the funds for research. Much of his work is supported by a large food company. Traditionally, research funded by the industry was viewed negatively in universities, but now it is seen as valuable, especially since the government wants universities to show their work has real-world impact.

Spence is currently assisting well-known brands in reducing salt and sugar in their products, which is important for keeping customers healthy. Interestingly, many companies make these changes quietly, so consumers do not notice the difference. Spence explains that when people are informed about these changes, they tend to focus on the taste and often dislike it more.

Spence first met famous chef Heston Blumenthal while working on a project for a major food company. At that time, people thought combining science and food was unappealing, even though food is inherently scientific. Blumenthal's partnership with Spence led to the creation of the "Sound of the Sea" dish in his restaurant. Spence notes that a century ago, Italian futurists experimented with sounds and food, but it did not become popular. Now, the food industry is applying Spence's research on sensory experiences to many products. For instance, he found that higher-pitched music can make food taste sweeter, while lower-pitched sounds can make it taste bitter.

An airline is planning to match music with the meals served to passengers, and a well-known brand recently launched an app that plays music while ice cream melts, although they did not match the music to the taste, which is often overlooked.

What are dinner parties like at Spence's home? One time, they had rabbit served with the fur around the cutlery, and another time, they experimented with remote-controlled, colorful light bulbs. They have even hosted dinner parties with tone generators, headphones, and various drinks to test how different pitches affect taste. For Spence, home, sweet shops, food conventions, and gastronomy conferences are all extensions of his research lab.

Text: 'Our brains are more active than ever. We are overwhelmed with facts, false information, chatter, and rumors, all pretending to be useful information that we must sort through to find what is important and what we can ignore. At the same time, we are doing more tasks ourselves. Thirty years ago, travel agents booked our flights and salespeople helped us find items in stores. Now, we handle most of these tasks on our own. We are managing the work of many people while trying to keep up with our lives, families, careers, hobbies, and favorite TV shows, with our smartphones assisting us. They have become part of the modern rush to fill every spare moment with activities. However, there is a problem. Although we believe we are multitasking – doing several things at once – this is a misleading idea. Earl Miller, a neuroscientist at MIT, explains that our brains are not designed to multitask effectively. When we think we are multitasking, we are actually switching quickly between tasks. Each time we switch, there is a mental cost. We are not like expert jugglers; we are more like amateur plate spinners, hurriedly moving from one task to another, neglecting the ones not immediately in front of us, but worried they will fall apart. Even though we feel productive, multitasking actually makes us less efficient. It has been shown to increase stress hormones like cortisol and adrenaline, which can overstimulate our brains and lead to confusion. Multitasking creates a craving, rewarding our brains for losing focus and constantly seeking new stimulation. Additionally, the prefrontal cortex, the part of the brain we rely on to stay focused, is easily distracted by new things. This is ironic because the very area we need for concentration is often sidetracked. Just having the chance to multitask harms our cognitive performance. Glenn Wilson, a former psychology professor, calls this issue info-mania. His research indicates that trying to focus on a task while an unread email is waiting can lower our effective IQ by nearly 10 points. Wilson found that the cognitive losses from multitasking are even worse than those caused by tiredness. Russ Poldrack, a neuroscientist at Stanford, discovered that learning new information while multitasking sends that information to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do homework while watching TV, the information from their studies goes to the striatum, which is for storing skills, rather than to the hippocampus, where facts and ideas are organized and made easier to remember. Moreover, multitasking often involves making decisions: ‘Should I reply to this text or ignore it? How should I respond?’ Decision-making is also taxing for our brains, and even small decisions require similar mental effort as larger ones. This can lead to a state of mental exhaustion, where after making many trivial decisions, we may end up making poor choices about important matters. In discussions about information overload with business leaders and scientists, email frequently arises as a concern. It is not a rejection of email itself, but rather the overwhelming amount of communication we receive. When the son of my neuroscience colleague was asked what his father does, he replied, ‘He answers emails.’ My colleague acknowledged that this is quite accurate. We feel we must respond to emails, but it seems impossible to do so while accomplishing anything else.'

In a Swedish zoo, a chimpanzee named Santino spent his nights breaking concrete into pieces to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In caves in the US, female bats help unrelated fruit bat mothers if they struggle to give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, these questions were often ignored. Animals had behaviors that led to measurable results, and science focused on those results. The idea that animals have thoughts, feelings, and moral systems was considered overly sentimental. However, this view has started to change. Research on the behavior of bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens has begun to explore animal emotions, which were once a taboo subject. This shift has influenced popular science books, like Mark Bekoff’s "Wild Justice" and Victoria Braithwaite’s "Do Fish Feel Pain?". This change has sparked a debate that may never be resolved: do animals have consciousness? This debate leads to another important question: do animals have a moral sense that guides their actions? 

In a recent experiment with cows, those that opened a locked gate to get food showed more joy—by jumping and kicking—than those that had the gate opened for them. If this research suggests that cows enjoy solving problems, what does it mean for how we produce and consume beef? While the observations may be accepted, their meanings are debated. Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, author of "Second Nature," argues that the logical response to this research is to stop eating meat. He believes humanity is on the brink of a major ethical change, similar to the abolition of slavery. Aubrey Manning, a professor at Edinburgh University, thinks we should reconsider our understanding of animal intelligence, suggesting that animals have a simpler version of our theory of mind. Professor Euan MacPhail believes we should avoid attributing human emotions to animals. These three perspectives may never agree because the core issue is not just scientific or moral, but philosophical. Since defining consciousness is very difficult, can we ever truly understand, as philosopher Thomas Nagel asks, what it is like to be a bat? 

Balcombe describes an important experiment he conducted that suggests starlings, a type of bird, can experience depression. In a study at Newcastle University, starlings were divided into two groups. One group lived in spacious, comfortable cages, while the other lived in small, bare cages. Initially, both groups learned to eat only from a box with tasty worms. However, when only unpleasant worms were offered, only the starlings in the comfortable cages would eat. Balcombe concluded that being in a poor environment made the starlings pessimistic about life. Balcombe, who has worked with animal rights groups, has a clear bias. He states, “We look back with horror on a time of racism. Our views on animals will one day be the same. We can’t support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger.” If he were the only one with this view, it might be easy to dismiss him as extreme. However, Professor Aubrey Manning shares similar views. Manning has written a textbook called "An Introduction to Animal Behaviour." He notes, “What we are seeing is a swing in perspective. At the start of the 20th century, some believed animals thought like us, and there was a backlash against that. Now we are moving back toward that idea. But it is a very controversial topic, and we should be cautious of academics with strong personal opinions.”

**Simplified Text:**

Critical thinking is a way of engaging with what we read or hear to gain a deeper understanding. Adrian West, a research director at the Edward de Bono Foundation U.K., notes that many believe that arguing helps us find the truth. While technology helps us store and process information, there are growing worries that it changes how we solve complex problems and makes real thinking harder. West points out that we are often exposed to poor but appealing ideas, trends, and opinions, which can overwhelm our ability to think clearly. Ironically, having more data does not necessarily lead to better knowledge or decision-making. West highlights that the quality of our thinking has not improved much despite the increase in information.

According to the National Endowment for the Arts, literary reading has dropped by 10 percentage points, and this decline is speeding up. Patricia Greenfield, a psychology professor, believes that focusing more on visual media has a cost. She suggests that the decrease in reading may be linked to a decline in critical thinking, as people are more focused on real-time media and multitasking instead of concentrating on one task.

However, there is no clear answer about how technology affects critical thinking. The presence of technology has made critical thinking more complicated, and scholars can no longer depend on the beliefs they once had. It is easy to see technology, like computers and video games, as either good or bad, but the truth is that they can be both, and different technologies can lead to different outcomes. For instance, a computer game might help or hinder critical thinking. Reading online can improve analytical skills, but constantly clicking on links can prevent deeper thinking.

Greenfield, who studied over 50 research papers on learning and technology, says that technology changes how people think. She observes that reading enhances thinking and sparks imagination in ways that visual media, like video games and television, do not. Reading develops imagination, reflection, and critical thinking, as well as vocabulary. However, she also found that visual media can improve some types of information processing. Unfortunately, most visual media are real-time and do not allow time for reflection or analysis. As a result, many people, especially younger individuals, may not reach their full potential.

How society views technology influences its understanding of critical thinking. This is especially clear in the debate about video games and learning. James Paul Gee, an educational psychology professor, argues that video games are not necessarily harmful to children. In fact, they can be a valuable learning tool. Evidence shows that playing video games can help children develop better reasoning skills. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and analytical skills in engaging, virtual environments that mimic the real world. These games also allow players to explore ideas that might otherwise be difficult to access. As reading and math scores decline in the digital age, it is important to examine how technology affects thinking and analysis.

When Matthew Crawford is not writing about how we should live, he works as a motorcycle mechanic. He chose this job after becoming unhappy with office work and his role in social policy. His first book praised the value of manual trades, while his latest book discusses how to handle modern life. He was inspired to write it when he noticed advertisements appearing on a credit card machine during a brief delay while entering his pin number. Crawford realized that these distractions are becoming harder to escape. What we focus on at any moment is personal, but we are often unaware of how outside forces influence our choices. It is increasingly difficult to think or remember conversations. To avoid constant interruptions, we isolate ourselves and may even stop engaging in simple interactions, like talking to strangers. Crawford notes that we often experience the world through representations designed to capture our attention, such as video games and apps, which can take over our desires.

Crawford is not alone in his concerns. Many office workers complain about emails but still spend their free time checking them. Research shows that our attention can drift if a phone is visible, a common experience for those who feel drawn to their phones during dull moments. While there is no scientific proof yet that our attention spans have changed, it is clear that we are more aware of other activities we could be doing. Some might think this issue is purely technological, but Crawford believes technology has simply amplified our self-obsession. With endless choices, our self-control is challenged, affecting our social interactions. We often prefer texting friends instead of risking a face-to-face conversation. By only interacting with digital representations of people, Crawford warns that we may lose something essential in our society.

Screens are just part of the issue. For example, in his gym, there used to be one shared music player, which could create tension due to differing tastes. Now, people listen to their own music through earbuds, and the gym has lost its social atmosphere. Genuine connections often arise from conflicts, such as differing opinions on music.

Crawford suggests a two-part solution. First, we need to regulate noise and distractions in public spaces. More importantly, he believes we should engage in skilled practices to connect with the world more meaningfully. He cites cooks, ice-hockey players, and motorcycle racers as examples of people who must interact with the physical world. No digital representation can match the real experience of feeling a hockey puck on ice or gravel under motorcycle tires. These roles require good judgment and the ability to navigate social interactions.

Crawford argues that engaging with the world in this way reveals how manufactured experiences are inferior to real ones. This does not mean everyone should become a chef, but it is crucial to find ways to use our judgment. There are many benefits beyond job satisfaction. Constantly fighting distractions can be tiring and make it harder to focus on what truly matters. In contrast, concentrating on one thing can improve our ability to pay attention to other things as well.

Text: 

"What do you do for a living?" This is a common question in small talk, as we often identify ourselves by our jobs. However, if you are a philosopher, like me, it can be more complicated. Saying you are a philosopher can sound pretentious. It feels acceptable to say you study or teach philosophy, but claiming to be a philosopher might suggest you think you have special knowledge or insight. This idea is misleading; philosophers are just like everyone else, but this stereotype makes me cautious.

So, why do people have this view of philosophers? One reason is that philosophers are seen as people who evaluate the actions of others and value intellectual life. The Greek philosopher Aristotle (384 – 322 BCE) believed that a life of contemplation, or philosophical living, was the best kind of life. While few modern philosophers fully agree, there is still a cultural connection between philosophy and intellectual thought. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said that "the unexamined life is not worth living," meaning that simply accepting societal norms without questioning them leads to dissatisfaction. Our ability to reflect on the world gives us control over our lives and helps us make our own choices.

However, living an examined life does not require extensive reading of philosophical texts or a life focused solely on intellectual thought. It simply means paying closer attention to our daily experiences to ensure they are meaningful. You do not need to be a wise person, separated from society, to evaluate life fairly. In fact, examining life can be very practical and should involve sharing knowledge, as it is vital for a good life.

This brings me to another reason for the misunderstanding about philosophers: as philosophy has become a profession, it has become more disconnected from the real experiences of people, especially those without formal training. This is not entirely the philosophers' fault; university funding and evaluations are linked to expensive academic journals, making it hard for philosophers to share their ideas with anyone outside their small group of experts. For many, philosophy can seem distant from everyday life. While some philosophers have tried to challenge this view, many have accepted it. The academic environment has led to a separation from society, and as discussions have become more technical, it has become difficult for those outside the field to understand them.

I sometimes call myself an "ethicist" because most of my work is in ethics, which is the area of philosophy that looks at human actions. Recently, I have felt that this title does not fully represent my work, as ethics is often linked to formal rules and values. There is a new trend in philosophical thinking where ethics is seen as applied ethics, which examines the fairness of specific social practices. The role of the ethicist today is to decide if certain actions are "ethical" or acceptable. These are important questions that I often explore.

However, philosophy is more than just this. A typical discussion might start by asking if illegally downloading films is unethical (it is) and then move on to consider our views on responsibility, art, and consumerism. In this way, philosophy can help people reflect on the practices and behaviors that shape their lives. Sometimes this reflection confirms what we already know; other times, it reveals that our beliefs are difficult to defend. Regardless, by examining these ideas, we contribute to the benefit of everyone.

Text: 'People who love food, like foodies, chefs, and gourmands, might think that thinking deeply about what and how we eat can enhance our enjoyment of food. However, historically, discussions about food in philosophy have often been secondary to other philosophical topics. When philosophers have discussed eating, it has usually been a metaphor for something else, like gaining knowledge. Sometimes, there are philosophical discussions that seem to be about food, but a closer look shows they are exploring different, loosely related ideas. 

One interesting example is the ancient Greek philosopher Epicurus, who promoted the idea of seeking pleasure and avoiding pain across various human activities. Despite this, Epicurus is often associated with a love for eating and drinking, as seen in the names of restaurants and food websites. Businesses likely hope to gain from this association with a famous philosopher. 

Food is inherently social and cultural. The food we eat comes from historical contexts and is shared within our communities. These communities provide us with dining companions and the systems through which food is produced and distributed. We interact with food more often and in more essential ways than with any other product, making it a clear subject for philosophical exploration. 

Once food is prepared, critics begin to discuss it. But why do these critics hold such a special status? One philosopher pointed out that tasting food is not a unique skill; rather, influential food critics are simply better at describing flavors. This area has been overlooked in philosophy, as most studies on perception have focused on vision, which should change. 

Another important aspect of food is its aesthetics. We often describe paintings or music as beautiful, but we rarely talk about the beauty of food's taste. Some philosophers argue that, with the growth of modern gastronomy, food deserves a place in discussions of aesthetics alongside art forms like sculpture or poetry. However, food is consumed and disappears when enjoyed, unlike visual or auditory art, which remains. Aesthetic objects need to last over time, so it is incorrect to consider food a proper subject of aesthetic value. 

There are also many ethical questions related to food. We can ask what we should eat: organic, free-range, locally grown, vegetarian, or non-genetically modified foods? The answers often reflect our ethical beliefs, and philosophers will question why we hold these beliefs, making such discussions about food worthwhile. 

Another topic is the difference between cooking at home and in restaurants. Home cooks have a special responsibility to their guests, based on love and friendship. In a home kitchen, everyone is included as we share food and companionship. In contrast, professional cooks have obligations to their employers and the food itself, meaning their kitchens are not open to everyone, and their relationships are more about colleagues than friends. 

A recent essay called ‘Diplomacy of the Dish’ explores how food and dining can help bridge cultural divides. This happens in two ways: first, we learn to appreciate others by enjoying their food, and second, we build personal connections with people from different cultures by sharing meals, a practice with a long history in international diplomacy. The text is enriched with many delightful examples and stories, making this aspect of food philosophy engaging for the general reader.'

Rob Daviau, from the United States, creates ‘legacy’ board games. He felt that the traditional board games he enjoyed as a child were no longer fun or challenging, so he began to think about how board games could change. Could they have a story? Could choices made in one game affect future games? He modified a classic game called Risk to create a new version: Risk Legacy. For the first time, decisions made during the game had lasting effects. Players might have to tear up cards, mark the board, or open packets with new rules at important moments. The games are played over a set number of sessions, and long-standing rivalries become part of the game. Daviau explained: “You could point to the board and say: ‘Right here! You did this!’”

Daviau was later invited to work on a legacy version of Pandemic, a very popular cooperative board game where players try to cure diseases that threaten humanity. His next project was a game called SeaFall. While Pandemic Legacy received much praise, SeaFall was seen as a true test of the legacy format because it was the first game that did not follow an earlier version. Set in the age of sailing (16th to mid-19th century), players become sailors exploring a new world. Designers of legacy board games must think about all possible player choices to keep the story coherent. To do this, they hire testers to see how the games develop. Jaime Barriga was a play-tester for SeaFall. He said, “It takes a lot of time. You might have a situation where the first few games are great, but then after four or five games, it starts to get shaky, and by game six, it’s broken. Then you have to go back and fix everything.”

Legacy board games were not expected to become very popular. When he was developing the idea, Daviau thought it would appeal to a small group. He said, “When I was working on it, I thought: ‘This is really different and I think it’s pretty good,’ but it’s unusual and breaks many rules. I thought I would be known as the guy who did this strange project.” However, many players, like Russell Chapman, loved the idea. He believes it is one of the biggest advancements in game design in recent years. He said, “It’s a new level of commitment, intensity, excitement. There’s nothing more thrilling for a board gamer than to learn a new game or a new way to play, and you get that constantly with legacy games.”

Another fan, Ben Hogg, said that the excitement of an unfolding adventure outweighed any worries about the game lasting. He mentioned, “At first, I was worried about making changes and possibly ruining my board, but that concern was eased by Pandemic Legacy. Most people don’t go to the cinema to watch the same film twice, do they? You’re buying into an experience. It adds a storytelling aspect similar to video games.” The legacy format is influenced not only by video games but also by the demand for episodic entertainment from popular TV shows. While in college, Daviau thought he would become a television writer, but he moved into advertising and then game design. Still, he loved telling stories. Pandemic creator Matt Leacock compared the legacy design process to writing a novel. He said, “You need to know how you want it to end and have a good idea of where to start, but it’s not enough to just have a general outline.”

While Daviau feels a sense of ownership over the idea, he is curious to see how others will develop it. However, he also tries to downplay its importance, thinking that gamers will soon ask, “What’s new?” Colby Dauch, the studio manager for the publisher of SeaFall, is less certain. He believes the legacy format has been a revelation. He said, “It’s the kind of idea that changes how you think about what a board game can be.”

Text: 'Recently, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He crawled across the floor and squeezed into a narrow drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story, which sounds like a children’s movie, became popular online. Part of the enjoyment comes from seeing animals as similar to us. Octopuses are especially interesting because they are very intelligent and look very different from humans. They can open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells for protection, and even play in complex ways. 

Some people think that seeing animals in a human-like way is unscientific. However, Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies primates like gorillas and chimpanzees, believes that it is actually a mistake to ignore the human-like qualities of animals. He calls this mistake "anthropodenial." After studying many years of research on animal intelligence, he shows that animals, except for having fully developed language, display many behaviors once thought to be unique to humans. These include thinking about the past and future, showing empathy, being self-aware, and understanding the intentions of others. In other words, animals are smarter than we often believe.

De Waal thinks that anthropodenial is a recent idea. In medieval and early modern Europe, people believed that animals had enough intelligence to be put on trial for crimes. Even in the nineteenth century, many scientists looked for similarities between human and animal intelligence. Charles Darwin, who changed our understanding of evolution, wrote that the difference between human minds and those of higher animals is one of degree, not kind.

In the twentieth century, behaviorism became popular, focusing on training animals through rewards and punishments. During this time, many people viewed animals as simple machines or robots with instincts. Those who believed animals had inner lives were often seen as unrealistic. This change in thinking happened at the same time that humans were destroying animal habitats, polluting the environment, and treating livestock poorly.

Fortunately, de Waal believes we are starting to recognize animal intelligence again. He notes that there has been a lot of new information about animal cognition shared online in recent years. He argues that the best tests of animal intelligence consider the unique traits of each species. For example, squirrels may not do well on human memory tests, but they can remember where they hid their nuts, something we often struggle with.

In her book, The Soul of an Octopus, naturalist Sy Montgomery suggests that if an octopus were to test human intelligence, it might focus on how many color patterns we can create on our skin. If we failed, the octopus might think we are not very smart. 

De Waal is cautious about Inky’s escape. He believes that while octopuses have escaped before, it might be too hopeful to think Inky knew how to reach the ocean. However, he understands how powerful stories like Inky’s can help people appreciate animal intelligence. He once conducted an experiment to see if capuchin monkeys could feel envy. When some monkeys received cucumbers (a food they like) and others received grapes (which they like even more), the monkeys with cucumbers became upset when they saw their friends getting grapes. This study was published in a well-known scientific journal, but what really made people believe the results was a short video of the experiment released ten years later. This shows how our unique way of thinking about animals can influence our understanding.'

Text: 'Robotics, once a topic in science fiction, is now set to cause major changes in technology, similar to the impact of industrialisation. While robots have been used in car manufacturing and other industries for many years, experts believe we are approaching a point where robots will be used widely in many areas. However, many people are not ready for this change. 

Most people see robotic automation as a disruptive force. Interestingly, about two-thirds of people think that robots will take over most jobs currently done by humans in the next 50 years. Yet, around 80% believe their own jobs will still exist in the same way during that time. This shows a common belief that our jobs are safe, but they are not. Every industry will be affected by robotic automation soon.

For instance, an Australian company called Fastbrick Robotics has created a robot named Hadrian X, which can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour. This task would take two human workers a whole day or more. Another example is Tally, a robot from a San Francisco startup, which moves through supermarket aisles to check that products are stocked, placed, and priced correctly, rather than cleaning the aisles.

Supporters of robotic automation argue that robots currently cannot maintain or program themselves, which could lead to new, skilled jobs for technicians and programmers. However, critics warn that we should not forget the importance of human skills in the workplace. They believe society is not ready for the changes that will come from reducing human interaction.

Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how this technology is changing the workforce. His recent report indicates that in two years, nearly one-third of robots will be smarter and able to work safely with humans. In three years, many top companies will have a chief robotics officer, and some governments will create laws about robots. In five years, salaries in the robotics field are expected to rise by at least 60%, but many jobs will remain unfilled due to a lack of skilled workers.

Zhang stated, ‘Automation and robotics will impact lower-skilled workers, which is unfortunate. The best way for them to adapt is not to rely on the government to protect their jobs, but to find ways to retrain themselves. People cannot expect to do the same job for their entire lives anymore.’

Additionally, advancements in motion control, sensors, and artificial intelligence will lead to new types of robots for consumers, including robots that can live and interact with us in our homes. This presents a great opportunity for companies ready to embrace these changes, but it also brings challenges, such as the need for new regulations to protect our safety and privacy.

With many jobs at risk and a global employment crisis approaching, it is essential to focus on education to prepare for the future workforce that will include robots. Developed countries need more graduates in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) to stay competitive.'

Text: George Mallory, a mountaineer, is famously quoted as saying he wanted to climb Mount Everest "because it’s there." This response reflects a common question people have: why do some individuals choose to engage in such dangerous and seemingly pointless activities? Mallory's answer may encourage others to pursue their dreams and face the unknown. However, it also suggests that the main reason for climbing could simply be for adventure and enjoyment.

In 1967, Bolivian writer Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay called "Games that Climbers Play." He identified seven different types of climbing activities, from bouldering to climbing high peaks, each with its own rules. He argued that the approach to any climb, such as the amount of equipment used, should depend on the specific rules of that activity. Over time, this perspective has become popular in discussions about climbing in the West, appearing in climbing magazines and casual conversations.

Many climbers love the sense of freedom that climbing provides. Yet, climbing can also feel restrictive. For instance, being stuck in a tent during a storm is not what most people think of as freedom. This creates a paradox in climbing. However, some argue that the limited choices in climbing can simplify life, which can also feel freeing.

When asked "Why climb?", US rock climber Joe Fitschen suggests a different question: "Why do people climb?" He believes that climbing is part of our nature; humans are wired to take on challenges and test their limits, even if it involves risks. Therefore, the joy of climbing may be more about our biology than logical reasoning.

US academic Brian Treanor adds that climbing can help develop important qualities like courage, humility, and respect for nature. While not all climbers show these traits, Treanor believes they are especially valuable in today's risk-averse society. Climbing, then, can have practical benefits, helping people develop the qualities needed to thrive in everyday life.

Another interesting idea is that climbers who depend on themselves rather than others or technology must be fully committed to succeed. Expert climbers Ebert and Robinson stirred some debate by claiming that climbs done independently are more challenging and deserve more recognition than those completed with teams or artificial aids, like bottled oxygen. This claim raised concerns that it might encourage climbers to take unnecessary risks.

Exploring climbing outside the Western perspective reveals that climbers often experience being "in the moment" or "in the zone." The physical effort, the meditative state while climbing, and the intuitive problem-solving involved are key aspects of the activity. Some argue that climbing techniques are similar to those in Zen philosophy, which aims to achieve a state of peace. This offers another perspective on why people are drawn to climbing.

Over six decades, pianist Alfred Brendel established a prominent place in classical music. He was an intellectual and sometimes serious figure who explored and recorded important European piano works. Although he wrote and performed a lot, he taught very few students. Those close to him saw a playful side, but this was rarely shown in his concerts. His life was a constant cycle of study, travel, and performance.

About four or five years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong approached Brendel backstage after a concert and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not take this request seriously. He had very few students and did not see a reason to start teaching now. He quoted another famous pianist: “You don’t hire a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.” However, something about the 14-year-old boy caught his attention. After listening to Kit play, Brendel thought, “I have to make time for him.” Kit played beautifully and had a rare ability to connect the music from start to finish.

As Brendel steps back from the public eye, Kit is starting to make his mark, though Brendel worries about him burning out too soon. Now 19, Kit is always busy, learning new languages, studying math, writing computer code, or playing tennis, all while his mother keeps a close watch. He also composes music. Brendel emphasizes the importance of learning to read music by trying to write it yourself. He noticed Kit’s incredible memory, excellent sight-reading skills, and his sensitivity to sound. Kit not only understands Brendel’s instructions but can also apply them throughout a piece of music.

Brendel is cautious about raising expectations. He dislikes when newspapers label Kit as the future great pianist of the 21st century, saying it can be harmful. Like many talented young musicians, Kit can play some pieces exceptionally well, while others require more time and experience. It would be unfair for critics to expect perfection from him.

Now at 80 years old, Brendel shows a softer side in his retirement. He reflects, “When I was young, I didn’t want to be famous quickly, but I hoped to achieve certain things by age 50. When I reached 50, I felt I had accomplished most of those goals, but I still wanted to do more, so I continued. Although I may not have the physical strength now, my mind is always active with many pieces I’ve never played. I don’t perform anymore, but I enjoy this new phase of my career.”

Text: "When I was a child, I thought gardens were beautiful places. My Grandad’s garden was by a river, sloping gently down to the water. Although you couldn’t reach the river, you could hear the water and the birds in the trees. I believed all gardens were like this – peaceful and quiet. Grandad’s garden was simple. He didn’t have a fancy greenhouse like some neighbors, who used old window frames and patched them with plastic where glass was broken.

At home, my father was often quiet and reserved. He had a sense of humor and enjoyed using phrases like ‘It’s immaterial to me,’ even though ‘I don’t mind’ would have worked just as well. Deep down, he might have felt disappointed with his life. He left school without qualifications and became a plumber, which he didn’t love. He wasn’t very ambitious, although he and my mother once thought about moving to Canada, but it never happened. He was skilled at home projects, creating amazing bookshelves and cupboards.

My parents only moved house once during their marriage, but my mother loved changing furniture. Just when you got used to one chair, another would appear. The biggest change was when a piano arrived. I wanted to like it, but it intimidated me. I only liked the two brass candlesticks on it, but my mother said they were too fancy and they disappeared while I was at school. I was never allowed to play the piano; my sister took lessons instead. When I later asked my mother why I wasn’t given the chance, she simply said, ‘You’d never have practiced.’

Of the three places to explore – moors, woods, or the river – I always chose the river. I could escape into my imagination there. With a fishing net and old sandals, I would walk along the riverbank, looking for a good spot to take off my sandals and search for fish. After failing to keep them alive in the backyard, I returned them to the water.

I wanted to leave school as soon as possible, but it seemed unlikely until one day my father said, ‘There’s an opening for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested.’ In that moment, he went against his usual judgment. He might have preferred if I became a carpenter, but I like to think he saw my passion for gardening. Even though he didn’t enjoy gardening himself, I believe he noticed my enthusiasm for plants and flowers."

Lawrence MacEwen is crouching on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck, and I am too. A strong Atlantic wind threatens to blow us off the steep cliff at our feet and into the ocean below. MacEwen’s sheepdog, Tie, approaches, and his owner gently strokes him. Despite the fierce wind, MacEwen feels completely at home on his island. He shows me around, pointing to nearby islands. “That’s Eigg to the north, and to the west is Rum, which gets a lot more rain than we do,” he shouts over the wind. I see dark clouds pouring rain on Rum’s tall mountains. “Beyond Rum is Soay,” he adds. 

Suddenly, MacEwen says he needs to move his sheep, and we start walking down the slopes. He shares interesting facts about the island: Muck is three kilometers long and one and a half kilometers wide; the geese here eat a lot of grass; and his family has lived on the island for 3,000 years. As we walk, Tie the sheepdog tries to herd the sheep but struggles. “Away to me, Tie,” MacEwen instructs, meaning the dog should go to the right, but Tie goes straight through the flock, causing confusion. MacEwen sounds disappointed, and Tie looks ashamed.

The Isle of Muck is mainly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence and his wife, Jenny, manage the farm; their son Colin takes care of the island cottages; and their daughter Mary runs the hotel, Port Mor, with her husband, Toby. Mary enjoys that her two boys can explore the island and sail dinghies during summer. “They leave the house and come back only when they’re hungry,” she says. However, living on the island has its challenges. For example, electricity is not always available. On my first evening, I anxiously wait for the lights to come on, and the next morning, I find Mary preparing breakfast by torchlight. I also have to deal with no mobile phone service. “You can get reception on the hill,” Mary explains. “Most people last a couple of days before putting their phones away.” I decide to do the same.

Life on Muck is full of surprises. A boat arrives today with groceries and three musicians who come to perform in the island’s tearoom. Their concert is a great success, and the islanders enjoy the music. That night, as I sit by a warm fire while it rains outside, Lawrence tells me how he met Jenny. “Her father bought a small farm on Soay after seeing it in a newspaper, without even visiting. He had never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it.” I ask if she knew how to run a farm. “She had good typing skills,” he replies.

I go to bed listening to the rain and wake up to more rain. However, I eat well, as most of my food comes from the island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish, which I bring back to her kitchen. By 7 pm, our fish is on the table, incredibly delicious. The next morning, I worry about my ferry ride to the next island. Many ferries had been canceled recently due to rough seas. If my ferry doesn’t arrive, I might be stuck on Muck for two more days, which, secretly, I would not mind at all.

Text: 'The game design industry was once mainly made up of computer scientists and self-taught individuals, and it didn’t offer many ways to enter. Often seen as just a hobby for young people, the video games industry is now taken seriously. This may surprise some, but industry experts are not surprised. However, entering this field is not easy. Video game spin-offs that come out quickly after a new movie need many team members and months of hard work and skill. Like many industries, getting into game design is challenging, but it is growing. Jim Donelly, a spokesperson for an online games magazine, says, “It’s very hard to make progress in big companies or to influence major mainstream games. But the industry needs game designers now more than ever. Not just top-level directors who manage entire games, but also those who design systems and individual parts.” 

So, how can you enter this competitive field? Many companies prefer candidates with a degree in computer science, but Jim disagrees. “The only way is to make games. The tools are available. You won’t get a job if you haven’t created something, and you won’t succeed independently if you aren’t making things. Game design is more than a job; it’s a way of life. Like any creative work, it must be practiced to be real.” Another expert, John Field, offers different advice. “While ‘just doing it’ is important, it’s more complex than that. Many people want to work in games, but few meet the industry’s requirements today; even fewer have the creativity, technical skills, vision, and entrepreneurial spirit needed to contribute to this evolving field.” 

Can you succeed on your own? “Maybe, but it’s quite difficult,” says John. “A good postgraduate course in games can help and provide valuable support and guidance. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and work their way up. They are interested in all types of entertainment and have a strong passion for the arts and contemporary culture. They may have spent some time working after graduation but have realized that games are their true passion. They are not just fans; they are excited about the future of games and understand the growing variety of the medium. Finally, networking is important. This is often overlooked, but to advance in games, as in many fields, you need to make connections.” 

The stereotype of a young boy playing video games has changed to a more accurate view of games as a serious medium that captures our attention. Families often engage with interactive consoles. Smartphones offer many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is much room for growth. “Games have become popular among larger audiences. They are also a great way to learn, and I see this already significant area as full of new possibilities and opportunities.”'

Text: "Since I was a child, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he never forced me, and I appreciate that. I had a friend whose dad was very demanding. He often said, ‘You can’t do this, you can’t do that.’ My friend could have been a good player, but he lost interest and stopped playing football. I’m glad that didn’t happen to me, but I know it could have been different. When I score an amazing goal from far away, people often say it’s just luck, but it’s not. I have practiced taking long shots since I was young. You can only score great goals by practicing. The best players in the world have natural talent, but they also practice for many years. Sometimes young players collide on the field, but I learned proper techniques. When I teach kids, I focus on helping them enjoy learning skills. At school, I played many sports, from rounders and baseball to athletics and basketball. I know now that education is important, but back then, football was my main focus. The teachers were doing a good job, but I didn’t realize it at the time. I want my son to have a different experience. We are already trying to read him books, even though he is too young to sit still for long. I hope that his habit of kicking the books around doesn’t mean he is just like me. 

At the start of my professional football career, the manager made sacrifices so that younger players like us could join the first team, but he never made a big fuss about it. He didn’t gather us and say, ‘This is your chance to prove yourselves,’ but we all understood the importance. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost, and a well-known TV presenter said, ‘You can’t win anything with kids.’ This made us realize how much we needed to improve. We had some doubts, but we believed in ourselves as a team despite his comments. I depend a lot on my close friends and family. However, having a lot of money can sometimes create issues. For instance, people often ask me why I let my mother keep working. I have helped my parents financially; I paid off their house loan and bought them a car last Christmas. My family is strong, and I think they would be upset if they felt they should rely on me completely. My mum doesn’t earn much as a hairdresser, but she loves her job. On the other hand, I enjoy using my money to help those around me. I have a lot of money, though not as much as people think, and it doesn’t solve all my problems. After I stop playing, I plan to take a year off or even longer to do things I haven’t been able to do. I want to go skiing the day after I retire. I can’t do that now because if I were to break a leg while skiing and couldn’t play football again, I wouldn’t be insured."

Text: 'Sam Carter was the reason we lived at Reef Point. He was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. Out of desperation, he offered to find us a cheap place to stay because my father couldn’t write anything while we were in Los Angeles, and Sam was at risk of losing clients and money. During the summer, the beach was often empty because sea fogs covered the sun. Reef Point rarely attracted day visitors. The road was not inviting, and the nice resort of La Carmella was nearby, so most people chose to stay there. Only those who were broke or really loved surfing would make the last mile to Reef Point. But now, with the hot weather, the beach was full of people and activities. My father was busy every day trying to finish a script, and he was in a bad mood. While he worked, I often went to the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. When we first arrived at Reef Point, we didn’t have a dog, but Rusty decided to join us. I tried to send him away, but he kept coming back. One morning, I felt sorry for him and gave him some water. My father threw a boot at him, but it was just a weak attempt to scare him off. Rusty knew this and got closer. I asked my father, ‘Who does he belong to? He acts like he belongs to us.’ My father replied, ‘You’re wrong, Jane. He thinks we belong to him.’ Rusty loved the beach and often dug things up to bring to me. Sometimes he found things that didn’t belong to him, like a new sneaker or a bright beach towel, which I had to return to their owners. He also loved to swim and always wanted to join me, even though I could swim much faster. You’d think he would give up, but he never did. That day, after swimming, my father had gone to Los Angeles to deliver his script, and Rusty and I spent the afternoon together in the sea. As the sun began to set, it got cooler, and we watched the surfers. They had been surfing all day and didn’t seem to get tired. They would choose a wave and balance perfectly as they rode it to the shore. One surfer caught my attention. She was so graceful that the others looked clumsy next to her. When she decided to stop, she rode in on a final wave. ‘Hi,’ she said, ‘why didn’t you join us?’ ‘I don’t have a surfboard.’ ‘You could get one.’ ‘I don’t have any money.’ ‘You’re British, right? Are you visiting?’ ‘No, I live here.’ ‘Is your father American?’ ‘No. He came here to write a film script based on a novel he wrote.’ ‘Really? Have I heard of him? What’s his name?’ ‘Rufus Marsh.’ ‘You mean, Tall as the Morning?’ I nodded. ‘I read that book from start to finish.’ She looked at me with new interest, and I realized that this was how it usually was. They were friendly but only showed interest when I mentioned Tall as the Morning.'

Text: "‘What have I done?’ Violet Hetherington wondered. She was in a long line at the dock in Southampton, waiting to board the Queen Caroline. The line was spilling out of the area marked ‘Departures’. Her friend Annie had told her, ‘It’s best to arrive late at the docks. If you get there too early, you’ll just be waiting around.’ Annie, who was married to a diplomat and had traveled a lot, usually gave good advice. But this time, she was wrong. 

After a while, an announcement came over the loudspeakers: there was a ‘breakdown in the computer system.’ This news made the atmosphere among the waiting passengers tense. Some tried to be patient, while others attempted to stay cheerful, but most people became frustrated. They had paid a lot of money for this trip, and many felt it was their last chance for a bit of luxury. The fact that they couldn’t board the ship smoothly did not bode well. Violet felt like leaving. She reached into her bag for her phone and realized it was missing. This was more annoying than the long wait. It made her question whether going on a cruise was a mistake. 

Now, she had the added problem of her phone. She couldn’t call the taxi company to see if she had left it in the cab because all her contact numbers were stored in her phone. This was the very mistake her older son Harry always warned her about. Behind her in the line was a friendly-looking couple. ‘I’m sorry, but I think I left my mobile phone behind. Could I borrow yours to make a quick call?’ Violet used the couple’s phone to call Harry and left a message asking him to ask their neighbor, Kristina, to check if the phone was left behind. If it wasn’t in her apartment, she would be in trouble, as she had no other way to find the numbers she needed in New York. Part of her thought, Thank goodness. But she didn’t tell Harry this. Harry believed he was more experienced than his mother, while Daniel, her younger son, was more understanding of her mistakes because he made them too. Dan might forget to pass the message to Kristina.

Eventually, the line started to move, and Violet approached a window where she handed over her travel documents and got ready to board. Her heart sank further when she entered the ship’s foyer, which looked like a not-so-grand hotel trying too hard. There were shiny fake wood panels, fancy chandeliers, polished brass, and carpets that looked like those in airports. Violet followed the signs to the ‘Elevators’, which were lined with mirrors and packed with tired passengers who might have preferred not to see their reflections. She was squeezed against the side of the lift as it moved up, stopping at each floor to let people out. Finally, on the twelfth floor, she stepped out into freedom. Thankfully, her room had the balcony she had requested. She had been worried about what to say if it didn’t. Ignoring Annie’s advice to wait for a last-minute deal, she had decided to pay the highest price she could afford to ensure she had a sea view."

Text: 'When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he had no idea he was uncovering the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was searching for images for a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago. Instead, he discovered 30,000 images taken by Maier, a street photographer known for her captivating photos. Since then, Maloof has built a collection of Maier’s life and work. In his home attic, he keeps her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm movies and audiotapes. One morning, Maloof looked around and realized he was on the brink of something significant, all by chance. ‘When I bought this, I had no idea what it was,’ Maloof said. ‘I could have easily sold it all to someone else.’ For a while, Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been piecing together details of Maier’s life. They reached out to families who had employed her as a nanny and spoke with staff from the shop where she developed her film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she returned to New York and moved to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier, who was somewhat private and unique, always carried a camera. She wore oversized coats, wide-brimmed hats, and sturdy shoes. ‘On her day off, the camera was around her neck, and we wouldn’t see her again until late at night,’ said Maren Baylaender, whose husband employed Maier to care for his daughter. ‘I remember her as a private person with strong opinions about movies and politics.’ Maier was knowledgeable about theater and film. Although she was not very social, she walked the streets with her camera and sometimes interviewed people on audiotape.
