She seemed to be dedicated to her ‘second job’ of documenting the world around her. ‘She was a true artist who followed her dreams,’ said Rydzon. ‘Nothing stopped her.’ Maier’s work is pure art; she did not create it for commercial reasons. Her images often focus on women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract subjects. ‘What is fascinating about Vivian is the number of interesting pictures,’ said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees influences from other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her own style. ‘Was Vivian sophisticated enough to do this on her own, or did she borrow ideas from others?’ Maloof often thinks about whether he will ever sort through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof file cabinets. Interestingly, he had no real interest in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural photos, Maloof began taking his own pictures. ‘As I improved as a photographer and revisited her work, I realized that the cityscapes were not what mattered to her. It’s the people, the street scenes, the overall composition,’ he said. ‘There was so much more to this work than I thought, and I realized I was holding something more important than I ever imagined. Now our goal is to share her name and ensure Vivian Maier is recognized in history.'

When a novel is called ambitious, it often suggests that it has not fully succeeded. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I interviewed her in the UK when her book was very successful, and she was at the center of a lot of attention. Despite being in her twenties, she remained calm. She had just arrived from Germany and was flying back to New Zealand the next day. She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She pressed her novel against the glass, and the official asked, “What’s it about?” This is not an easy question for an author. 

The Luminaries takes place in New Zealand during the 1860s, where a series of crimes have occurred, leading a council of 12 men to come together to solve them. The plot becomes very complex. Catton intended to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but she found that the past allowed for more complications and misunderstandings for her characters. At over 800 pages, the book is “big by necessity” because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a fair chance to shine.

When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she responded thoughtfully. “It’s nice coming from a small country because everyone feels part of the success. There’s a family-like feeling at home; I received a lot of support from other people’s grandmas.” She also mentioned that it annoys her when people assume her book is not a philosophical work.

Catton explained that she wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral, with each part being half the length of the one before it. This structure makes the story speed up as it progresses. I asked if it matters whether readers notice these patterns. She said she aimed to create a book with structural patterns that readers could discover if they chose to look for them. 

Despite its unique structure, The Luminaries remains an exciting murder mystery with a captivating plot. Interestingly, Catton did not plan the story in advance. “I would write myself into a corner and then see how creative I could be to get out of that situation,” she said. One of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers. 

We also discussed her love for television dramas, noting how The Luminaries uses cliff-hangers, multiple viewpoints, and dialogue. I asked if she would consider screenwriting. “That could be pretty cool,” she replied, her enthusiasm evident. She becomes animated when discussing her writing and New Zealand. “I notice how much my imagination changes when I’m in a different place. I understand why writers leave New Zealand for more populated areas to experience the energy of other people.” For now, New Zealand will remain her home, and I hope it continues to inspire her for many more novels.

**Simplified Text:**

As a boy, Jonny Kinkead spent his time either building things in his dad’s garage or playing the guitar. For the last forty years, he has made steel-string acoustic guitars by hand. He says, “I am still amazed by the guitar. How can two pieces of wood create such a beautiful sound? Different types of wood make different sounds, and that still fascinates me.”

Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. Instead of getting a job to buy one, he decided to make it himself. He studied how different shapes and types of wood affect sound and how to put them together. The bass guitar was the first instrument he built from scratch, but he had been building model boats and planes with his brothers for a long time. His father taught them how to use tools, and Jonny had also repaired instruments for his friends.

Although Jonny’s bass guitar turned out well, he hadn’t thought about making guitars as a career. He was also interested in painting and sculpture. After finishing school, he chose to study architecture at university because it involved design. However, halfway through the course, he dropped out because he felt too different from the others. He realized that guitar-building was a form of sculpture that involved creating sound, and he thought it might be a more practical career than pure art since people actually use the guitars.

Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he worked part-time cleaning windows to earn extra money. His first guitars were sold for just the cost of materials, but as he became known as a skilled guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, he says he is “still scratching a living.” He can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income.

In the early years, Jonny focused on getting his name out there. He attended music festivals on weekends, letting musicians try his guitars and encouraging them to share his name with others. He also had to learn how to price his instruments, which was difficult for him.

Jonny believes it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. “When I started, many people thought only American-made acoustic guitars were good,” he says. “UK-made guitars were not seen as valuable, even though we have always had good training programs here. Now, our handmade guitars have the reputation they deserve.”

He thinks new instrument-makers should take courses to learn valuable techniques, but he also believes that learning through trial and error is important. “You should look at other instruments, see what works and what doesn’t, and try different things,” Jonny advises. “If you make the back too thin or too thick, the sound won’t be good. Learning from someone else teaches you only one way, but being self-taught, like I was, helps you learn everything.”

Text: "When discussing English conversation, we often start with the weather. This is a common practice, and I will reference the well-known statement by the 18th-century writer Dr. Johnson, who said, 'When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather.' This statement is still true today, just as it was over two hundred years ago. However, many commentators stop here or struggle to explain why the English seem so focused on the weather. They often make a mistake by thinking that our discussions about the weather are genuinely about the weather itself. They assume that English people talk about the weather because they find it interesting. 

For instance, the American writer Bill Bryson points out that English weather is not particularly exciting. He notes that in England, we do not experience extreme weather events like tornadoes or blizzards, which are common in other places. In response, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman argues that English weather is indeed interesting. He believes that the English fascination with the weather is not about strong feelings; rather, it is about its unpredictability. He states that while we may not have tropical storms, living on the edge of an ocean means we can never be sure what the weather will be like.

From my research, I believe that both Bryson and Paxman miss the main point: our conversations about the weather are not truly about the weather. Instead, talking about the weather serves as a way for English people to connect with each other. For example, phrases like 'Nice day, isn’t it?' or 'Ooh, isn’t it cold?' are not really questions about the weather; they are common greetings or ways to start a conversation. In this sense, English weather talk is similar to 'social grooming' seen in monkeys and apes, who groom each other to bond socially.

There are specific situations where weather talk is used. Some writers claim that English people talk about the weather all the time, but this is not accurate. In reality, there are three main contexts for weather talk: as a simple greeting, as a way to break the ice before discussing other topics, or as a fallback topic when conversations stall and there is an awkward silence. This does lead to a lot of weather talk, which makes it seem like English people discuss it constantly. An English conversation might start with a weather greeting, include some ice-breaking weather talk, and then return to weather talk during pauses. This is why people from other countries, and even some English commentators, think that English people are obsessed with the weather."

Alice Leader stood in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain, explaining to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds what an amazing engineering achievement it was for the Romans to build a structure that is 120 km long and 5 meters high nearly 1900 years ago. The students were excited about this trip, choosing it over more glamorous tours to Spain, Greece, or France. However, they were curious about why the Wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not enough. Unable to find a suitable historical novel to provide context about life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After retiring from teaching for 31 years, Alice began her new career as an author in 2001. 

Although she had a successful teaching career, Alice felt she was stepping into the unknown. She compared teaching to acting, saying it was physically demanding, while writing was exciting but less exhausting. Her former colleagues envied her because she still connected with children through her stories. Alice aims to fill a gap in children's fiction, noting that much of today’s adolescent literature focuses on negative experiences or is purely fantastical, like Harry Potter. Her books are different from both.

Alice always taught English and History together, using lessons about ancient Greece alongside the novel "Tale of Troy." She is motivated by her love for children and is fascinated by the moment when a child goes from boredom to interest and from confusion to understanding. She enjoys the challenge of engaging bored children, seeing it as her responsibility to make learning exciting.

Her desire to write her first novel was partly inspired by the approaching "empty nest" as her two sons were leaving home, and a surprising recommendation from her head teacher to attend a creative writing course. Initially, Alice was hesitant, thinking she didn’t need the course after 25 years of teaching. However, she had to submit her best piece of fiction to be accepted, and just days before the course, she quickly created a story about a Roman couple expecting a baby. After three hours and 30 pages, she submitted it and was accepted.

During the course, her classmates reviewed her work positively and encouraged her to publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing skills, she requested a year off from her school to write her first novel. Alice's husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and his help was crucial in editing her novel. She believes they complement each other; he focuses on improving her writing, while her instinct is to keep adding more scenes. This difference highlights the roles of a fiction writer and an editor.

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to participate in a special race. This race would have Jonny racing in a car on the roads, while Alistair would race on a mountain bike across the countryside. The race took place in the beautiful and rugged Yorkshire Dales in northern England, starting at Semerwater lake and finishing at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, which is about 350 meters high.

As they prepared for the race, Jonny expressed his excitement, saying he had never done anything like this before and was looking forward to the beautiful views from the car. Alistair, dressed in warm cycling gear, was also eager but joked about Jonny’s driving skills, saying he might stop for tea during the race.

The race began, and Alistair quickly took off on his bike, heading straight up the hill. Jonny got into his car and started driving. However, just 15 seconds into his drive, he encountered a large tractor blocking the road. He complained to the cameraman about the delay, saying if Alistair won, it would be because of the farmer.

Once past the tractor, Jonny continued driving, while Alistair struggled with the steep incline. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, which was a strange sight for the sheep nearby. After a tough climb, Alistair finally reached the top and began to pick up speed as he rode down the other side.

Meanwhile, Jonny faced more challenges on the narrow roads of Yorkshire, which were not designed for fast driving. He carefully navigated through tight corners and a stream on the road. Both brothers were unaware of how close they were to each other as they approached the finish line.

As Jonny accelerated towards Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing through his last field and back onto the road. When Alistair reached the finish line, he looked around and asked if Jonny was there. When he found out Jonny had not arrived yet, he celebrated his victory. Moments later, Jonny arrived in his car, disappointed but congratulated Alistair, saying he was upset about losing.

Text: 'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your shot. The well-kept grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all create a calm atmosphere that protects you from the outside world. The quiet of Centre Court helps my game. What I struggle with most in a tennis match is to focus only on the game and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by loud applause and cheers when a point ends. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t realize there are fifteen thousand people watching every move I make. I am so focused that I don’t think about the millions watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, taught me from a young age that this was the most important tournament. By the time I was 14, I was sharing my dream with friends that I would play there one day and win. Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice – in the final the year before and the year before that. The loss in 2006 was not too hard. I was just happy to have made it that far at twenty. Federer won easily, more easily than if I had believed in myself more. But my loss in 2007 was devastating. I knew I could have played better; it was not my skill that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that loss. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and let it slip away. Toni, my tough coach, usually doesn’t comfort me, even when I win. It shows how upset I was that he told me not to cry and that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand; this might have been my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete's career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment matters, but some moments matter more, and I had missed a big one in 2007. There was nothing Toni could do to ease my pain. But he was right in the end. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I had learned from my defeat; this time, my mindset would be strong. The best sign that I was ready was my belief that I would win. At dinner with family and friends the night before the final, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t tell them not to mention it, but they understood that I was already preparing for the match in my mind. From that moment until the match started, that space in my head was mine alone.'

Text: In early April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, “I am living in the Africa I have always longed for.” Her name was Jane Goodall, and she would spend most of her life in Africa as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, the National Geographic Society helped make her famous by publishing articles and documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writings, including popular children’s books and the bestselling book In the Shadow of Man, published in 1971, which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real accomplishments. Many articles and interviews tell her life story, but they often focus on sentimental aspects and do not fully capture her work. She has been portrayed in various ways: as an adventurous girl, a privileged woman who wanted to live with wild animals, and a determined feminist. These portrayals can diminish her true contributions. 

Based on academic references to her research, the success of her students in biology, and the extensive data from her forty-year study, Jane Goodall should be recognized as a pioneering zoologist. More simply, she opened our eyes to the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools, and we did not realize they share emotions similar to humans or have social systems like ours. Goodall discovered that chimpanzee communities in Africa have unique cultural traditions. Her book, The Chimpanzees of Gombe (1986), is the most important work in chimpanzee research and serves as an encyclopedia on the subject. Her long-term study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and influenced how humans view themselves, as chimpanzees are our closest relatives.

Even as a child, there were signs of the person she would become. One clear example occurred in the autumn of 1939 when she was just five years old. One day, she disappeared, prompting her mother to call the police. Neighbors and family members joined the search. After a frantic search, Jane reappeared alone, with straw in her hair and clothes. When her mother asked where she had been, Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she had crawled into a henhouse, hidden in the straw, and stayed still for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This moment can be seen as the start of her journey as a biologist.

Text: 

In our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voices of a playful 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to fans of children’s TV shows and cartoons, as well as those who have seen computer programs about health and safety. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she explains, “so I had to quickly learn how to say many medical terms.” 

Shirley shares what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors, even well-known ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,” she says. “But there’s more to it. You need to bring the script to life for an audience that can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions because of their fame, but often they don’t get the roles because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.”

After school, Shirley joined a drama course, hoping for a traditional acting career. During the course, she occasionally sang jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she recalls, “the studio manager suggested I try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I didn’t study drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, surprisingly, got a major role.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character, her brother, and her mother.”

Adult female actors often provide voices for young boys and girls because their voices are lighter than those of male actors. Hiring child performers involves complicated procedures and many forms, which production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds and to vary her voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the best part of her job, which also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my experience helps,” she says. “I’ve learned that the trick is to smile while you talk – it makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a big difference.”

The competition for voiceover work is intense, and having a good showreel – a recording that showcases what the artist can do – is crucial. “It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley advises. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she has reached the top of her field through determination as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.”

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley suggests attending “specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.” She also thinks a love for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and becoming the characters she plays. “If I’ve been in the studio doing a specific American voice, for example, it can take over, and I’ll speak like that for hours, maybe even days,” she says. “My children have grown up hearing their mom talk in completely different voices.”

Text: "People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is understandable because cartooning is a job many dream about as children, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually give up these childhood dreams and choose more practical careers, such as tax lawyer or auto parts manufacturer. The idea of making a living by drawing simple pictures, like those in high school notebooks, seems silly at first. Yet, some people do just that. 

Becoming a cartoonist is not the same for everyone, but most who succeed have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist, loving comic strips, contributing to school publications, and being known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, I showed my illustrations to different companies. I was fortunate to find someone at a newspaper looking for political cartoons about local issues. I created a few ideas, they liked them, and soon I was earning enough to support myself.

You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be a great artist. You just need your mind, your hand, and something to make marks with. However, if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as there are teachers. While the technical requirements are low, it is still a challenging job. One should only pursue this career if they feel they cannot do anything else. It is much easier to find a regular job that pays the bills and allows time for family, home repairs, and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living from your art. I have created political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also worked as a writer, caricaturist, and designer. I accept all kinds of work because you can learn a lot, even from jobs you don’t want to do. It helps to be intelligent, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of cartooning? In the past, many cartoonists could find steady jobs with different newspapers and magazines. However, those days are fading. For most today, cartooning is an entrepreneurial activity, meaning you must not only create the work but also sell it. The more comfortable you are with this process, the more successful you will be. I have seen many cartoonists with average creativity but strong business skills do much better than those who are very talented but lack other skills.

It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ circle it, and write your name and the date next to it. But realistically, it’s more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it’s not a disaster – it could actually be a lucky opportunity!"

Text: "Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. Among other items, I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate getting rid of even useless items, so why did I want to throw this one away? I took it to the dump and was about to leave it on a pile of trash when a young man approached me, looking confused. 'You’re not going to throw that away, are you?' he asked. I told him I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could take it, and I said 'Yes.' We parted ways, but in the following days and years, I felt a deep sadness for what I had done.

Then, a few months ago, I received an email that changed my life. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it ten years later in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I opened this email from someone I didn’t know, a guitar dealer and restorer named Keith Rushton. He told me, 'I’ve got your electric guitar.' It had been sold several times since the young man at the dump took it. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back of the guitar. He realized it was probably outdated but used my name to find me online. He eventually contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was overwhelmed with emotion. I would have given him anything, but his price was very fair. I had forgotten that my dad always put name-and-address stickers on my belongings, including my guitar. How my dad would have laughed at this strange situation!

My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar when I was young, as it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the calming sound of the classical guitar, which was forgiving to beginners. Unlike the violin, it didn’t sound terrible when played by someone just starting out. However, I struggled to improve, so I switched to the electric guitar, playing simpler songs. This was also the time of punk music, where anyone could be a rock star, even if they weren’t great musicians.

When I took my old guitar out of the box that Keith sent me, I vividly remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play but quickly stood up, putting a strap over my shoulder because electric guitars are meant to be played standing. My fingers instinctively knew where to go. I couldn’t have drawn a diagram for the chords, but my hands just moved into position. My middle-aged fingers felt the familiar pain of pressing down the strings to play a chord. The electric guitar is not really a solo instrument. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I’ll need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe we can play together. Or perhaps there are others my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves 'The Regainers!'"

Text: 

Recently, there has been much discussion about sleep. When I wrote the book *Insomniac*, which focuses on people who struggle with sleeplessness, I felt like I was one of the few warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and emotions. Anyone who has trouble sleeping knows that sleep is essential for our overall well-being. Interestingly, those who find it hardest to sleep often understand its importance the most. It is encouraging that sleep is finally receiving the attention it deserves. However, I wonder about dreams. There hasn’t been much talk about them. We often lose our dreams. When you wake up early, missing the last hour or two of sleep, you mainly lose REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep, which is when most of our dreams occur. Our most vivid and powerful dreams happen during REM sleep, especially just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM, meaning that someone who lives to be 90 years old will spend around six or seven years in this stage. When researchers prevent people from experiencing REM sleep, they find that the next night, the amount and intensity of REM sleep increases to make up for it. This suggests that dreams serve a purpose.

When REM sleep was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was key to understanding our minds. However, later research did not support this idea, and the focus shifted to the physical reasons behind dreams rather than the psychological ones. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, according to Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. 

Dreams are significant. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams much better than others. He concluded that the use of dreams increases with a person's interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams, as film is one of the most dream-like forms of human expression. However, I wondered if only creative people benefit from their dreams. Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? 

Stickgold explains that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from our past and present to create new associations. Dreams may help us discover new patterns and combinations that challenge our usual ways of thinking. For instance, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They tend to think outside the box and combine ideas in unexpected ways, which is a key aspect of creativity. Personally, I find that I write better after experiencing intense dreams. Even a difficult dream, or one that I can barely recall, seems to inspire my thoughts. On those days, words and images flow so quickly that I can hardly keep up with my typing. I don’t fully understand how this happens, but it does seem to work. 

Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and everyone needs their brains to function well. We all need to think creatively and flexibly as we interact with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important.

Text: 

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, which has a stunning view of the sea, you see several empty frames on the walls, along with happy photos of her two daughters. As a leading artist in the copyist art movement, who can recreate the beauty of early 20th-century impressionist paintings and 16th-century Caravaggio portraits, it seems unusual that she has no paintings of her own. “I don’t keep any,” Susie says casually. “Once I finish them, they go.” The reason is that Susie is very popular. Over her 30 years as a copyist artist, she has painted works by many famous artists, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that art experts often mistake them for the originals. While the original paintings can sell for millions at auctions, her copies sell for a few hundred to £12,000, depending on how much time she spends on them. Susie does not reveal most of her clients, even when asked, but they include galleries and private collectors. While many collectors truly love art, some are more interested in status. One famous buyer likes to show off his “Van Gogh” painting, which is actually a “Susie Ray Van Gogh.” “Many well-known people pass off my copies as originals,” she says. “That’s their choice.” Some collectors save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank safe and displaying Susie’s copy instead. 

Susie has always been honest about her work. When she copies an old masterpiece, she aims to make it look as real as possible, believing that doing a poor job would disrespect the original artist. However, she signs her name on the back of the canvas. Selling a copy as the real thing is illegal, and although she knows people who have profited from that, she has never been tempted. Those who create fakes often face serious consequences. Susie mentions that she isn’t wealthy and has faced challenges, but her situation is more stable now, and it wouldn’t be wise to risk her reputation with collectors and artists. 

Susie didn’t always work as a copyist. After earning her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, earning very little. Looking back, she sees that it helped her develop skills for her current work and sparked her love for plants, even though it was hard to make ends meet. She explains that she had to be very precise and get things right on the first try. She has no regrets about that time but is happy to have found a more financially rewarding career. When younger artists ask her for advice, she emphasizes the importance of learning to draw accurately. She also highlights how much she has studied to master her craft. Her training allows her to create everything from plant drawings to perfect copies of 15th-century masterpieces and 20th-century abstract art, although she now focuses on French impressionists, particularly Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. 

Susie notes that many people think modern art is simple, almost like child’s play. However, she believes that impressionists painted quickly and freely, but they were also very careful, making their work more challenging to replicate. Given her talent, it seems strange that Susie doesn’t create her own art. Isn’t art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She explains that her work is the result of years of training and dedication, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried creating her own pieces, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—acceptable, but not impressive. It’s like living on plain food after enjoying meals prepared by a top chef. What stands out about Susie is her perfectionism.

Text: 'During her racing career, Ellen MacArthur was deeply passionate about the sea and being the fastest on it. This obsession began in her childhood. She felt a unique connection with the boats that took her around the world; they worked together as one. When she returned to land, everyday life felt unimportant, and she often longed to be back on the ocean, challenging nature even in places that had almost defeated her. After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo, non-stop round-the-world race, she invited me to see the small, stuffy cabin of her boat, Kingfisher, which had been her home, workplace, and survival space for 94 days. She shared how meticulously she planned her supplies, calculating exactly how many rolls of kitchen paper she would need. Preparation was crucial, she said. She proudly displayed her unappealing stock of foil-wrapped, freeze-dried food, a tiny gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies. Her attention to detail in keeping the boat was as impressive as her sailing skills. The boat was her entire world, and she cared for it because her life depended on it. Now, she views the world as a boat: a small, beautiful, fragile thing with limited resources. 

Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she assisted with a bird survey on albatrosses. ‘It made me stop and think. It gave me space to see things differently and realize ideas I hadn’t considered before.’ The many abandoned whaling stations served as a warning to her. ‘It felt like we just took what we wanted and moved on. That’s our behavior.’ When I arrived at Ellen’s office, she was finishing a heated conference call. She then explained why immediate action is necessary to protect the planet. ‘Coal, oil, and gas are no longer being made. They are precious resources we have only once. We need to find ways to avoid wasting them. Initially, my message was negative – to use less – but I gradually saw another perspective.’ Now, she focuses on reusing materials, passionately discussing items like reusable industrial carpet tiles. For the past three years, she has been visiting factories, mines, and power stations, speaking with government and business leaders about our dependence on non-renewable resources. ‘I will never be an expert,’ she admits. ‘But I absorb information like a sponge. I couldn’t ignore the current situation. Compared to this, sailing felt selfish. This is about discovering how my voice can be most effective. It truly matters.’ She also founded the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that collaborates with businesses and educational institutions to inspire young people to rethink and redesign a sustainable future. ‘I do miss the adventure of being at sea,’ she says. ‘It defines who I am. You feel connected to everything around you. There’s no time to feel lonely. You focus on records, practical matters, and survival. My new message will never be as simple as saying: “I’m going to be the fastest around the world.” I may have been the fastest, but this work surpasses everything I’ve ever done.’

**Simplified Text:**

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous among teenagers. He hopes to encourage other kids to explore the outdoors instead of just playing on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero." Climbing Everest is just one part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people achieve this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he becomes a teenager.

I spoke to several experienced Everest climbers, and none thought it was a good idea to take a 13-year-old up the highest mountain in the world. They agreed that a young climber might be strong enough physically, but they were unsure if a teenager could handle the emotional challenges. They also questioned whether a young person could have enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing.

The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, "I know there is criticism, but I can't focus on it – we have a lot to do. I think about possible problems, of course. Karen and I always consider the risks, but we believe our experience as climbers will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is getting stronger and more mature."

I also wonder about Jordan's reasons for wanting to climb. Is this just a father pushing his son to achieve something dangerous? Paul insists, "This project is not about me wanting to be famous through my son. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later in life, but we decided, 'Why not do it now?' We talk to him often to ensure he still wants to do it."

When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about this challenge, he says, "I just focus on reaching my goal." In the past, few people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record-setting event. The more exciting the record, the more attention it gets. This creates a problem for Jordan. While some people say that focusing on achievements can take away from the enjoyment of challenges, if Jordan wants to inspire others, he needs to engage with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He has to do something impressive, like climbing Everest.

Paul adds, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will end this project and go to the gym."

Text: 'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s likely they are not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they usually don’t know who he is. I have just started a music degree, but my classmates know as little about classical music as most people our age. If you don’t know who composed the music, you probably don’t own any of their recordings. This situation is concerning for classical music lovers. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music events, and the average classical recording sells only about 300 copies. This is hard to believe. So, why is there less interest in a music style that has existed for centuries? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is that classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the main buyers of music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who enjoy classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I’m not a big fan of classical music. I like many styles, but my classical music listening is probably close to that 3% figure. 

So, why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, can be challenging for us. We prefer fast conversations, quick games, and rapid thoughts. Experts say we struggle to pay attention for more than three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but just right for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to enjoy, while understanding classical music takes time and focus. Additionally, pop music often deals with topics that interest teenagers, unlike long classical pieces without lyrics. 

The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families would gather to make music together, and playing an instrument was valued. Now, you can find any music online, but classical music is rarely part of our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music in a store? One of my teachers says that audiences at classical concerts have grown recently. Maybe, but I doubt many of those new attendees are teenagers. In my orchestra, we perform classical music in various places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. I don’t know why more people enjoy classical concerts as they age, but I do know that if teenagers’ parents love something, they often try to avoid it. 

Some believe that schools are to blame for teenagers’ lack of interest in classical music, but many kids are eager to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they perform, but it’s not their preferred music otherwise. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we always choose pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham stepped out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you regret I came here,” she said to the school, smiling. Her mother was getting out of the other side and didn’t hear her, but Bonnie wouldn’t have minded if she had. Her mother understood how Bonnie felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was an unusual school, with buildings scattered among the trees on a hillside; it was quite confusing at first. Then she noticed the signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” Bonnie said, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” her mother replied. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path that curved through the trees. “I wish you’d walk next to me instead of trailing behind like a dog,” Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t seem to expect Bonnie to do so. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his study, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she thought. “I’ll be kicked out soon anyway, so I might as well get it over with.” She left the building and headed towards the riding centre, following the sign. There was a charming old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but there was no one in sight. She approached the horses with a sense of respect. The horses were well cared for, and she noticed that immediately. Almost every stall was occupied, and she walked along, carefully observing each horse. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, gently touching its nose. The next horse caught her attention. “But aren’t you the best of the bunch!” she exclaimed. He was brown with a bit of white. Lively, which Bonnie liked. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…” Above the stall was his name: Maverick. Suddenly, she couldn’t resist the urge to ride him. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle. They can’t be far.” Bonnie was thrilled to find that the room with the riding gear was unlocked. Engrossed in the fun of putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she climbed onto the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in control of everything around her. Her nickname at her old school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed happily as she remembered it. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said with admiration. “I’m serious, I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else.” She nudged him into a walk, then a trot. “If I stay here, I think you and I could become great friends,” she confided. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was thrilling, a gentle breeze brushing past her cheek. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he would jump well.

Text: 'I have met Cody Simpson before and have always admired his calm confidence. The 15-year-old Australian has already released many successful songs. So how did a relaxed surfer end up performing in front of thousands of fans? “I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven,” Cody recalls, explaining how it all started. “But I was swimming and surfing every day. Those activities were more important to me back then; I had a full life and many things to keep me busy. When I was 13 and in high school, I posted a few videos online.” These videos changed everything. He began by sharing a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans commented online, asking for more videos. So, Cody, who had recorded more at home, was happy to share. The responses were overwhelming. Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with top coaches and focused on perfecting his sport. But then record labels showed interest, and he faced a tough decision: stay in Australia and continue swimming, or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the leap. “It was very hard for me – especially at such a young age – to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 and trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?” He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the States. “It surprised most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid,” he says, remembering their shocked faces. “I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to stay that way in this crazy industry.” So Cody packed his bags and moved with his family across the world, giving up one dream to pursue another. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and isn’t directly involved in his career, they support him from the background. Cody believes it’s important to have a close circle of good people around you to stay grounded. Of course, everyone has moments of doubt. “Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How does my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight, and he’s traveling the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life,” Cody admits. “I worry about how that affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support me in everything I do.” Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to your big opportunity, even when it’s a bit scary. “It all happened so quickly and unexpectedly,” Cody says. “Now, I’m visiting countries I never thought I would see and performing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s something many people dream of achieving. But I know it won’t last forever.”

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked down at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbags, which were there to stop the buildings from flooding as the river ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting them into place. Last week, I had worked long hours with most of the town’s adults, showing I could handle the job. My grandfather didn’t seem to notice. With one hand on the curtain, I scanned the half-mile stretch of steaming black water created by the release pipe from the wood processing factory in Milltown. Fragile ice shelves lined the sides, and solid ice was downstream. As I took off my pajamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the far side of the river. I didn’t recognize him. I frowned. Amazingly, he was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain – a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from an expedition in South America. This chain is much more special than having a famous grandfather, and only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have his diary from that journey, which I keep under my pillow and read before I sleep. I touched the chain again and walked to the kitchen. 

“Morning, Rex,” my mom smiled as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training session. Be careful.” 

“Thanks, Mom.” I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he stepped out of his room. 

“Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” 

“Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was obvious from my wetsuit, and he had seen me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it’s been harder lately. 

“What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His harsh words hit me hard. I took a deep breath and counted to three. He crossed the hall and slammed the bathroom door. My mom came in with a sympathetic smile. 

“Don’t mind him. He’s…” 

“...not himself right now,” I finished for her. I held back from saying he had always been like this. But, like Mom, I try to be kind to him. When I was a child, he was my hero – ever since he first showed me photos of himself in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang framed on his bedroom wall, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own face in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, this grumpy old man. 

Mom smiled. “At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even on these cold days!” 

I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It’ll be warmer in South America,” I said. “If I find sponsors for my expedition.” 

She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried towards the boathouse.

Text: 'Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. “Come with me,” she said. Jess followed her into the study, where she saw an unframed painting on the table, leaning against the wall. It was clearly one of Grandpa’s works, but it looked different from his usual style and was obviously unfinished. “Do you know anything about this?” Mum asked. Jess shook her head. “I’ve never seen it before. I didn’t know he was working on anything.” 

Jess looked closely at the painting. A river took up most of the scene; it was not a river she recognized, and it might not even be real, just a fantasy. The painting was strange and beautiful in a haunting way. The riverbank was barely visible, just a hint of green that the eye almost missed, drawing attention to the pale waters leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people; it felt right that way. It seemed there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, she felt drawn to it, thinking of autumn coming after a long summer.

Mum spoke again. “It has a name.” There was something in her voice that showed her excitement. Jess understood why; Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted and let others interpret them. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud: “River Boy.” The words felt strangely significant to her, but she didn’t know why. 

Then she noticed something else. She looked at Mum. “There is no boy.” 

“Exactly. It’s strange, isn’t it? For him to be so specific. But he hasn’t finished it yet, so maybe he’ll add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it.” 

“Mum! You should have known better.” 

“I know, but I couldn’t help it. It’s such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can guess his response.” 

Jess didn’t need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. “He told you it’s not the artist’s job to explain a painting because each one has its own life and language, just like a poem, and we either understand it or we don’t. He said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to everyone…” 

“Mum, he said ‘ignoramus.’” 

“… every ignoramus what it means. If artists had to explain their work to everyone who asked, they’d never get anything done. And he said…” Mum interrupted, laughing. “Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him.” 

“Inspire?” 

“Someone who motivates an artist.” Jess knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but he usually said it to describe how the muse wasn’t helping him that day or that he needed to be nice to the muse because he had a tough part to work on. He never suggested that the muse was her. In fact, she always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a real person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. “He doesn’t need me to inspire him,” she said. “He’s been painting all his life.”'

Text: 'This morning, I didn’t plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad’s Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have accidentally gone into the carpet and made a big hole. I’m not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn’t wake up thinking, “Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.” It just seemed like a good idea at the moment, as things often do. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but by then it was too late. This happens to me quite often. 

What I was really doing was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It’s very cute! It’s small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and milkmaids. Now, I keep my collection of shells and fossils there. Gran knew I loved her corner cabinet, and I was excited when she gave it to me! 

The problem is, it’s a corner cabinet, which means it has to fit in a corner. I only have two corners in my small bedroom, which is shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is for Mum and Dad; the back one is my sister Angela’s; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s; and my room is the size of a broom cupboard. Mum says when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. When Tom goes to university, I can choose any room. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I’ll be stuck in my small room for a long time. 

I don’t mind; I like my little bedroom. It’s cozy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. Then I thought, if I can’t cut the cabinet, why not cut a hole in the carpet? It seemed like a good solution. Dad calls this lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to “think outside the box.” And that’s exactly what I was doing!'

The novel "The Borrowers" tells the story of a tiny family that lives secretly in the walls and floors of a house, borrowing items from the larger humans to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the book, I knew it would be challenging to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong opinions about how things should look. I used the original illustrations from the book a lot because I wanted to avoid criticism. The author wanted the series to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, which made filming more complicated. 

A key aspect was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing adventure, we had to position the camera ten times further away than usual. To capture the Borrowers' perspective, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters. They went through many pairs of jeans! We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. 

One major challenge was creating realistic shadows when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized background. We developed a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous director George Lucas called to ask how we achieved it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floor, filled with oversized objects to make the actors appear small. It was wonderfully surreal. I remember asking them to carry giant scissors, and they really got into it. The coins we used were larger than dinner plates and hard to lift, often making the crew laugh, which sometimes interrupted filming.

In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, the actors had to go down a tunnel with hoses, and they found it so scary that they didn’t need to act. A crucial part for me, which other directors struggled with, was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they would stick out like dolls' clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to move; she couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because regular fabric would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail with the costumes!

Most of the action away from the Borrowers' home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was difficult for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of each scene to show how they should look, and by the end, I had created 2,000 drawings. They weren’t perfect, but they were helpful. The budget didn’t allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly; I once filmed an entire scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But in the end, everything came together, and I believe the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Text: 'Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, expecting journalists that aren’t there. I wonder how long it will take for the chaos to start. It always does. The fake smiles, the people who want to be my friends, and the ones asking for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. “Everything will be fine,” I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to escape my old life on the road with tour tutors. While the rest of the band is renting here for recording, we are staying for good. I insisted on coming to this school because I want to meet real kids. How about a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns? That would be so cool. 

I walk into the school’s main office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I tell the secretary. “Name?” She looks unfriendly. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. The secretary seems confused. “Oh,” she says and types “McGraw” on her keyboard. That’s good because few people recognize my last name since my dad uses his stage name. “What grade?” “Eleventh.” “One moment, it’s printing,” the secretary says. Then she rips the sheet and hands it to me. English Literature, first period. Great, I can handle that. English has always been my favorite subject. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look foolish searching for my classes. 

When I reach the door, I hear the teacher taking attendance. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” She continues while I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. She looks at my very normal outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! Nobody will suspect me now! “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with embroidered flowers. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher pauses in the attendance. “Desert... McGraw?” she says carefully. “Here.” The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and eventually gives us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us about the books we need to read this year, she actually lets us socialize! All teachers should understand how important this is. 

“So why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have many options. Do I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? “We need a change, Desert,” he said, “and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.” Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose South Beach Sounds, a recording studio so close to the sand? “My dad had to relocate,” I tell her. Yes, lies work better. “What does he do?” she asks. Oh, whatever. Everyone will find out eventually. But at least I’ll have some time to pretend to be normal until they do. “He’s an artist,” I say, playing with the zipper on my backpack. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” And she doesn’t seem to care. Great.'

Text: 

Today, American teenage girls are expected to be very active. They often need to be the president of the Student Council, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in all these areas. Being an average teenager is no longer enough. Many believe that not having high ambitions is a sign of laziness. Kristen Loose, a teenager, explains that adults often forget how much pressure teenagers face. They have a lot of homework, tests, extracurricular activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to maintain a social life.

Despite these pressures, negative stereotypes about teenagers still exist. They are often seen as lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers may fit these stereotypes, many do not think it is fair to label all teenagers this way. Loose points out that people assume teenagers spend most of their time on their phones or watching TV. She admits to having her phone nearby but uses it for important tasks, not just for fun. For many teens, their phones help them manage their lives better.

With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their homework anywhere. Instead of just listening to music on the way to school, they might listen to language lessons. Schoolwork now requires attention all day and night, which can be exhausting. Many teenagers start their day around 6 or 7 a.m. and often stay up past midnight. Their days are filled with school, activities, family duties, and homework, leaving little time for sleep. The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of teenagers get the recommended nine hours of sleep each night. Additionally, 28 percent of teens reported falling asleep in school at least once a week due to lack of sleep.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says she has about 18 hours of free time each week, which is not much considering there are 168 hours in a week. She does not spend much of that time on social media or TV; instead, she focuses on volunteering. Olsen believes that many people think teenagers are only interested in themselves. However, she finds joy in helping others and looks forward to making a positive impact in her school and community.

In the future, the stereotypes about teenagers may change, but they will continue to challenge these views and make a difference in the world. There will always be new generations of students who are making their mark before they even finish school.

**Simplified Text:**

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded by wilderness east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In recent years, this group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This ongoing science project is both an astronomy experiment and an outdoor adventure, which is likely why teenagers join. I visited them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or piece of metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a bright trail of light.

As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the bottom of the balloon. Inside the lunch box were a camera, an altitude measuring instrument, and a thermometer to check temperature changes as the balloon rose. Two GPS trackers were placed on the outside of the lunch box to help find it later. A gas tank, given by a supporter from a nearby state, was used to fill the balloon, which slowly grew to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour trip to get the gas tank. “I didn’t really mind,” he said. For kids in this club, that’s normal.

Finally, it was time for lift-off. “Five, four, three, two, one,” they counted down, and the balloon began to rise. Some of them ran and followed its path with bright flashlights until they could no longer see it, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There was a quiet moment filled with wonder. Then the balloon vanished into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside, looking at a sky so clear that it was hard to believe they were only four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with about 4 million people. I saw a boy climb into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. “We’re the only ones talking,” said one girl quietly. “I know,” whispered another. A meteor streaked across the sky.

As the balloon rose, the air pressure decreased, causing the balloon to expand until it was almost the size of a house. Then it popped with a loud bang. A parachute helped the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students would find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Retrieving it wasn’t easy, but that was part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in remote areas. “Recoveries are a big part of the program,” said the group’s leader, noting they’ve only lost two lunch boxes in 53 launches. “Part of the journey is getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.”

On this occasion, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. “These students are familiar with the Eastern Sierra,” their leader said. “What seems wild and dangerous to some is just a normal part of life for others.” In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, near a waterfall. The camera didn’t capture any shooting stars. While this was a bit disappointing, it also led to a discussion about atmospheric waves and how they might behave above mountains. And it became another adventure story to share with anyone who asked.

Chloe Morgan admits that she was not very interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she turned fifteen. Her interest began by chance when her younger brother was fascinated by dinosaurs, a phase many children go through. Although she initially dismissed his interest, she helped him with a science project and found an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology that amazed her. She realized she wanted to pursue this field.

Chloe recalls meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already well-known despite his young age. She felt nervous at first, worried he might see her as just an annoying kid. However, she felt more comfortable when he showed patience and listened to her questions.

When discussing how palaeontologists are portrayed in movies and TV shows, Chloe expresses her frustration. She acknowledges that films like Jurassic Park have increased public interest in dinosaurs, but they often misrepresent palaeontologists. She feels they are either shown as eccentric geniuses or socially awkward individuals, which does not reflect the reality of their work.

Chloe explains that her job is diverse. She spends time digging for dinosaur bones, working in laboratories to analyze fossils, and writing scientific papers. Although not always required, she also believes in the importance of communicating scientific findings to the public, especially to young people. She wants to inspire them to learn about science, using dinosaurs as a way to spark their interest in the natural world.

Chloe contributed to the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs, where she provided advice to ensure accurate portrayals of dinosaurs. She found it easy to help because there were few inaccuracies to correct, mainly ensuring that the dinosaurs shown lived during the same time period. The documentary attracted viewers of all ages, showcasing the latest knowledge about dinosaurs, which differ significantly from those in movies like Jurassic Park.

Chloe believes dinosaurs continue to captivate us because they represent the explorer within us. They spark our imagination and the desire for discovery. In a world that feels smaller, prehistoric creatures remind us that there is still much to learn, and Palaeontology offers a unique way to explore the past.

Text: "I want to say this clearly: when you are traveling by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know that you are not ‘there yet,’ even if you keep asking, ‘Are we there yet?’ The truth is, once you arrive, it’s not ‘there’ anymore; it’s ‘here.’ So if you think you might be ‘there’ already, you should ask, ‘Are we here yet?’ I’m sure no one wishes to be ‘there yet’ more than the parents who hear that question repeatedly on long car trips. Think about it. Wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat, with no responsibilities? You could watch DVDs you’ve never seen, listen to music, or do puzzles you’ve had for a long time while enjoying the beautiful views outside the window. Meanwhile, in the front seat, there’s a parent with a map, giving out juice boxes and cookies, adjusting the radio, and making sure everything goes smoothly. 

But then, someone in the car does something annoying—usually my younger brother, Tim. He might put his foot on my side of the seat. I can’t let that happen, so I put my foot on his side. Soon, he’s leaning over into my space, and a fight starts. The driver and the other parent have to reach back to separate us while the car swerves. They tell Tim to stay in his seat and keep his hands to himself, which calms things down for a bit. 

As we drive on, I try to read, but then I feel a draft on my arm. The window isn’t open, so where is it coming from? Tim is next to me, quietly blowing his breath in my direction. He’s not touching me, so he thinks he’s being clever. This makes me angry. Tim gets yelled at again, and the car swerves more. Eventually, things calm down again. 

Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to handle us in the back seat. When we ask, ‘Are we there yet?’ he often replies, ‘Yes, we’re here. Get out of the car.’ But we are still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour. Then he says, ‘Oh, well, maybe we’re not there yet.’ This keeps us quiet for a while. You can tell when you finally arrive because the adults jump out of the car and move as far away from us as possible after all those hours. So remember: if Mom and Dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no. You’re not there yet."

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and board games. They hope that customers will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains their motivation: “There’s so much technology. Everyone is busy on their phones and gadgets. We wanted to bring people together in a way that doesn’t involve screens. It’s natural for people to connect and communicate.”

The games played in their café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games often have gentle themes, like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources, keeping everyone engaged until the end, so no one feels left out. This idea was further developed in ‘co-operative’ games, where all players work together to win or lose as a team, encouraging more social interaction. One popular co-operative game is Pandemic, designed by North American Matt Leacock. In Pandemic, players must work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings, which is based on the book. He recalls, “When I played that with friends, we felt scared and excited. In the end, everyone felt good, whether they won or lost. I wanted to create something similar.”

Leacock’s love for board games began in childhood, when he often felt disappointed after playing. “Games were my favorite birthday gift,” he says, “but I would get excited, open the box, and then feel let down.” With help from his game-loving uncle, young Leacock would redesign games to make them better. Pandemic became a huge success, and its follow-up introduced even more storytelling. Leacock explains, “It’s like an electronic game where you develop characters, learn new rules, and the story evolves.”

Interestingly, the growth of the video game industry has helped the popularity of modern board games. Many people now play games on their smartphones, making them more open to playing board games. Ben Hogg, who works for a major games company, says, “Everyone is a mobile gamer now. Most people with smartphones have at least one game they enjoy.” 

For a while, video games allowed some social interaction, like playing together at arcades or on the couch. However, as multiplayer games moved online, players became physically distant from each other. This led some former video gamers to seek out ways to play games with people in person again. 

As seen in John and Zuzi's busy café, tabletop gaming has become more than just entertainment. In our increasingly online world, games are now something to be shared directly and physically, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has created and produced some of the biggest hits in the UK in recent years. His story shows that endurance and persistence are crucial in the music industry, even if your career starts with many setbacks. He mentions that his mother was an "amazing singer" who encouraged him to play the guitar. The only radio station he listened to at home was a local one aimed at middle-aged listeners, which influenced his musical tastes as he grew up. He was 12 years old when he first heard a modern song. Around the same time, he had to choose between playing tennis, which he did at a national level, and pursuing music. He often spent his lunchtimes in the school music room learning songs on the piano. He recalls, "I was quite good at tennis, but it wasn’t what I wanted to do forever. It was just too much hard work."

At 17, he left school to become a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who was a decent guitarist but not as passionate about performing. Jamie remembers telling his parents, "This is what I want to do. I’ve been writing lyrics in economics class and playing the piano every day while others were outside." His father gave him 18 months to succeed; if he didn’t, he would need to find a job. After several close calls with record labels, he was signed by a music publisher at 19 based on one song. However, the labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend.
