Ultimately, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. However, fame and success did not come easily. He reflects, "In my own artist career, I feel like I’ve often been in the wrong place at the wrong time. But as a writer, I’ve been in the right place at the right time." Writing for other artists is where he truly excelled. He believes he is one of the main writers that UK labels turn to for new artists, helping them launch their careers.

Sometimes, he has to explain to the artists he works with that aiming for chart success is not something to be embarrassed about. He asks, "Why don’t you want to? Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?" He emphasizes that they should aim to create something amazing that will also sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone in pop music openly express their desire to write hit songs. Jamie is not arrogant; he simply understands that he wants to write number one hits and has the talent to do so. Instead of worrying about how others perceive him, he focuses on his goals. He states, "When I go into the studio, we need to aim for global success and write the best music for next year. It’s not just about what’s trendy; we want to create classic modern pop songs."

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity: a big star online, but likely unknown to those who don’t watch videos of people doing bike stunts. He is a ‘street trials cyclist’—he jumps from difficult places like roofs or walls to land safely in other challenging spots. These stunts are filmed and shared online. When I interview him one Saturday morning at a BMX park, the local kids recognize him, and even some older people come to show their respect, calling him ‘an absolute legend.’ After seeing his skills, I agree with them. I came with doubts, but I am impressed by his bravery, creativity, and willingness to take risks. Before each stunt, he explains what he plans to do, and I often can’t believe he will succeed. However, when I compliment him, he seems uninterested and a bit down. Despite his online fame, Tony says he is not comfortable with being a celebrity. He finds the social aspect challenging. He understands the importance of connecting with fans, but he prefers to focus on doing stunts rather than talking about them. This is ironic because his fame comes from social media and the small cameras that capture his stunts. He reflects, ‘This technology allows people like me to earn a living.’ He feels that many people are always filming themselves or looking at screens, and he doesn’t fully agree with that. Still, he is not complaining. Through his videos, he makes a good income from what would have been just a hobby in the past.

After years of interviewing top athletes, I’ve learned that two key factors help a passionate child become a top competitor: energy and the ability to handle emotional disappointment. These traits may be more important than talent and help build the mental strength needed to keep going despite failures. In the park, Tony fell a few times on what he considered easy but new challenges. He simply got back up and kept trying until he succeeded. Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some think he is reckless and takes too many risks. He responds, ‘Those who criticize me may care, but they don’t understand. They probably haven’t ridden a trials bike and don’t know the sport. They don’t see that I get advice from experts to reduce risks.’ In reality, Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He explains, ‘People are different. Some never feel scared, and they shouldn’t be doing these sports; it’s important to recognize the dangers. The rest of us can be divided into those who can overcome fear and those who can’t. I belong to the group that feels fear but finds a way to move past it. I’m not addicted to risk; I spend a lot of time planning and preparing. Sometimes, I ride around for a while to get in the right mindset before trying a new stunt. I know I must stay calm just before I jump. If I fully commit, I’ll be fine.’

Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on many dangerous challenges for charity, such as running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon River in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net; she only had a belt around her waist connected to another wire above her. To help her balance and avoid falling, she used a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen trained with an expert high-wire walker. Although she had some circus skills, she found that high-wire walking was very different. “The training was a shock,” Helen said. “I didn’t know how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and then another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so I could keep going if I slipped. Every time I fell, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I got nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!” On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen calmed herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. “That was the scariest thing I’ve done,” she said afterward. “I’m glad it’s over!” Despite this experience, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by skiing, kiting, and biking.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. He had previously written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motorsport and worked building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and also used it for a holiday in Amsterdam. He said, “That trip opened my eyes. I decided to see the world by bike.” Jeff wanted a unique touring bike and decided to build one himself. He thought a penny farthing would be the most interesting choice, so he visited a museum to learn how they were made. After two attempts in 2001 and 2003, which ended due to a knee injury, he finally began his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries across four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. He noted that while he met cyclists who could ride up mountains, he never regretted using his penny farthing. The further he traveled from home, the more people were amazed by it. His toughest experience was having to drink dirty water from a stream, which caused him a serious fever. He spent ten days in a hostel without medicine and had no money for hospital bills or a way to get home. Despite these challenges, Jeff now says, “If I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.”

I work at a university in the United States, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have recently started using a new tool called a ‘night-vision scope’ that helps us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about black ducks because their population has decreased significantly, and we are unsure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We have a lot of information about their activities during the day, but we know very little about what they do at night because we did not have the right equipment. This new scope will give us clear images, even on nights without a moon, allowing us to learn more and make better decisions about protecting their habitat.

Our work is challenging. There are four of us, and each of us works six hours a day. We have studied ducks in various locations, and I have had to take a boat to some sites and record every duck I see. The weather has been difficult; some nights are warm, but many are rainy. It is so quiet that I have needed a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one workday because the snow was too deep for our special vehicles. Despite the challenges, I enjoy this work, especially when I think about the summer, which will involve long hours in a laboratory analyzing our findings. Being inside will be tough, but it is necessary. I wouldn’t change this experience for anything!

Text: "When I tell people about my job, they often find it hard to believe it exists. But I’m serious! I spend my workdays tasting chocolate! Tasting is a crucial part of ensuring that customers receive high-quality chocolate bars from my company. Each week, I get samples, which are small amounts of chocolate from our factory, and I need to check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, to select the best ones for our chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I create, and I share samples with my colleagues! My kitchen is filled with machines and ingredients to experiment with. It’s great to have a private space to go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I work in our food lab, and other times I travel abroad to buy raw materials, which can be challenging since I have a young family. However, I enjoy the variety and lack of routine in my job, although I think the chocolate itself is the best part! People often ask me if I ever get bored of chocolate. I’ve worked with it for a long time, and I’ve never felt tired of eating it. In fact, I often go home and enjoy more chocolate in the evening!"

Text: 'Have you ever thought about what it’s like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a place that teaches young people circus skills. She says her course is popular because it offers many skills, such as juggling, throwing and catching objects like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which involves flying through the air in front of an amazed audience. 

During the year-long course, students gradually take more risks in each class, and parents can attend some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, “For a career in the circus, performers need to avoid doing the same thing repeatedly – it’s essential to keep performances exciting and dynamic. If you want to succeed in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great aspect is the friendships formed with other performers and the opportunity to learn from them. Staying fit is also very important – circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is crucial, but the best performers are those who are determined to succeed, have creativity, and continuously work on improving their skills. 

People often believe that injuries are common or that you might only work for a short time each year. However, the real challenge is planning for the future because you can only perform while you’re young, and then you need to think about other career options.” The course also includes business planning. Many former students have started their own businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia cautions, though, that it’s not a profession for making a lot of money! “The work usually does not provide a regular salary. It’s also competitive – but a lot of fun!”'

Text: 'You may not know her name or face, but you have likely heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer, someone who sings in the background to support the main singer. Many people believe that backing singers are not as talented as lead singers, but that is not true – they often have to be even more skilled. People like Mariam are the true stars of the music industry! 

“What I love about my job is that when I enter the recording studio, I never know what I will be asked to sing,” she says. “It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes, it might even be a silly tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never complain; I just do my job!”

“Excellent musical skills are crucial for my work, along with the ability to learn quickly. There is often no sheet music to follow. I will always remember my first experience recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different part, along with an orchestra. I was very nervous: I knew that if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are already long enough.”

“One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers sometimes do not know which musical range works best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to improve it.”

Text: 'Starting with only basic knowledge of fashion, Julie Deane built a successful business selling ‘satchels’ – traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular among many celebrities. Before deciding on satchels, Julie considered various business ideas, from cake decorating to party planning, rather than just going with her first thought. Once she made her choice, not everyone supported her. Julie recalls, ‘Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced.’ She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had never had a career but had a natural talent for business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children’s storybooks. Although Julie was not familiar with fashion blogs, they played a key role in her success. Initially, she sold about one satchel a week. To generate interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her products grew, along with the speed at which her company produced the satchels. Julie now enjoys waiting to see which celebrity will be seen with a satchel! While other companies spend money on online ads, she uses the online community for ideas on new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a difficult time when another company copied Julie’s design to sell similar bags. As a result, she now ensures she has confidence in her production team, just as she does in her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices – people enjoy working there. There is now a new factory, and while the buildings are important, it is the team that makes it a special place.'

Text: 'When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents allowed her and her brother Jamie to choose how they spent their free time. Vicky enjoyed participating in various sports. She was a talented swimmer, and her coach believed she had the potential to become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard for her to balance training with her schoolwork. As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and began competing. Vicky found this exciting and decided to try cycling too. She later said it was the best choice she ever made. Soon, she was cycling daily and performing well. The track was close to her school, so attending training sessions after school was easy for her. Vicky eventually had a successful career in track cycling, winning several competitions. When she turned 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky explained, ‘For years, I enjoyed winning, but I started to feel tired of it all – when the excitement fades, it loses its meaning. Fortunately, I found a new career.’ Vicky began working for a charity called CycleZone. ‘We help young people who have never liked sports,’ she said. ‘Our first step is teaching them to ride a bike. We want them to learn to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does important work, bringing young people together to form a community.’ The charity uses celebrities to promote their efforts. Vicky mentioned, ‘Some people doubt that celebrity support is always beneficial for a charity. They argue that celebrities may be more interested in their own image, which can overshadow the charity's real work. However, if famous singers and actors can help, I believe they should.’

Singer-songwriter Ana Ronson grew up in Ireland. Even though her parents were not musicians, music was always present in their home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of an audience was at school, but she was so nervous that her teacher had to take her off the stage. This teacher suggested that she join the school theatre club to build her confidence. After participating in the club for some time, she happily sang with 50 other students at an end-of-term concert.

A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, "Falling Stars," in just three days and enjoyed it so much that she signed up for a songwriting course with a professional. Although she was the youngest student, she knew more about music than many of her classmates. However, Ana felt that the teacher did not listen to her, which inspired her to write the song "Something to Say" about her frustration. She shared this song online, and it became very popular. She was thrilled when people commented that they loved it and found new meanings in it each time they listened.

Joss Alton, the owner of a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled from the other side of Ireland to invite her to join the company. At first, Ana was unsure because she did not know much about Isotope and did not want anyone telling her what to sing. However, Joss convinced her that this would not happen. Soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope, and all the tickets sold out quickly, making it a wonderful evening.

Ana prefers to write songs about difficult times rather than happy moments, as she feels there is more to express. One of her favorite songs is "Decision," which is about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it affected him. While she hopes her fans will enjoy her music, her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Text: 'Last year, I went on an incredible trip – a guided boat tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and wanted to write articles about the journey. He loves boats, although I don’t share that interest. I had dreamed of visiting this area since I saw it on TV as a child, especially because it was where our great-grandparents lived before moving to Europe. I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally agreed! A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we were visiting. Fortunately, the weather forecast for our trip was calm seas. I was busy with work and didn’t have much time to prepare, but Harry assured me he would handle everything, so I stopped worrying. 

After arriving in Canada, we met the group, packed our supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide mentioned that very few people live along that coast, and indeed, the only other creatures we saw that first morning were dolphins and birds. We could see islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far, so I focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water. We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of colorful fish, many of which I didn’t recognize. It was wonderful to forget about how fast or slow the day was passing. We never forgot lunch or dinner, which we all prepared together over campfires. When we finally fell asleep on the boats each night, even though the beds were hard, it felt like a stress-free life! When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I return to normal life? But I knew I would miss my family and friends if I stayed. I was also excited to share our adventures with everyone at home!'

Text: "My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. When I was a child, I watched many of his games. You might think that this would make me love basketball, but it did the opposite. I enjoyed telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I often brought a book to read instead of watching the games.

When I started secondary school, I was still two years away from being a teenager, but I was already two meters tall. Seeing my height, my sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I liked the practice, but I thought I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real game. The teacher believed in me more than I believed in myself. After some time, I agreed, and a few weeks later, I played against another school’s team. My parents watching made me more nervous, but it turned out fine!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did very well, even joining an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trained Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn’t enjoy living far from my parents at first. At home, I hadn’t spent much time with friends because of all the training, so that part wasn’t a big change for me. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly too!

I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I needed to gain weight to match my height. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it."

Text: "Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college and needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. After thinking about different options, I decided to train as a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. I took visitors around the city and was surprised by how much I enjoyed giving tours. I saw the city I had lived in my whole life from the perspective of tourists, and it felt like a new experience each time! After finishing my studies, I chose to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but when I researched what was required, I learned that to get a license as a full-time tour guide, I needed to know much more than I had learned so far. All Chicago guides must answer many questions about the city, including local architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging but interesting months, I earned my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent tour guide. 

Tour guiding is not just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group in crowds. There are many other important skills. You need to be entertaining and tell interesting stories, and most importantly, you must be able to adapt to changing situations. For example, if a place you planned to visit is closed or if the route changes, you need to handle it well. Tourists do not want to hear about problems or feel like they are missing out; they just want to enjoy a well-organized tour. I must ensure that visitors are happy with my tours, or they might leave a negative review online. Like most tour guides, I understand that these reviews are very important because good reviews attract more customers. That is why making tours enjoyable and stress-free is essential. For me, the enthusiasm and energy I put into my job usually lead to very good reviews, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago."

Text: "My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I traveled to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. Even though she is five years younger than me, we have a good relationship. We went to volunteer at an elephant sanctuary, a place where people care for sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was unsure if we would connect with the other volunteers because they were much older than us. We were also nervous since it was our first experience doing something like this. However, we ended up having a great time. 

One of our main tasks at the sanctuary was to gather food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of our day. Josie found it challenging, but seeing the elephants enjoy their food made it worthwhile for me. We also washed the elephants in the river with large brushes and soap, which I found very enjoyable, even though I got wetter than the elephants!

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By moonlight, we led the elephants into the forest where they spent the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a small bedroom because she didn’t want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we were prepared for that. The meals were delicious and did not include meat, which we both do not like. After dinner, all the volunteers and staff would spend the evenings talking and playing games.

Now that we are back in the UK, Josie doesn’t often mention Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. I think she might be a little upset with herself for not fully enjoying her time there because she missed her friends. However, when she reflects on the experience, she realizes how fortunate she was to go. Maybe she will return one day – I definitely will!"

Text: "My name is Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers not just to individuals but to various customers, including hotels and offices that use flowers in their reception areas. Sometimes, we provide flowers for businesses' advertising photos. Once, I even decorated a castle for a wedding, which was a lot of work, but I felt very proud of it.

My day begins at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep, and my friends think I’m a bit crazy, but I love what I do. It can be cold and dark at that hour, but I don’t let that bother me. The flower market is amazing, filled with flowers from around the world. The beautiful sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were picking for myself, I would choose pink flowers because they are my favorite. However, I have to remember that my preferences may not match what my customers want. Not all flowers are available all year, so I sometimes can’t find what customers ask for.

I don’t enjoy negotiating prices with the flower sellers, but it’s part of my job. Flowers can be expensive, so I try to get the best price. When I return to the shop, we review customer orders and prepare vases with the flowers I bought. Then, we create flower arrangements and calculate the costs. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes need to ask them to reconsider their choices. Some might think this is too much work, but I enjoy figuring out how to create beautiful arrangements within a budget. That’s part of selling flowers, and I wouldn’t want to do anything else!"

Text: "My city has a modern cinema that shows the latest films and many children's movies on weekends. It is close to my home, but a year ago, I realized I wanted something more – the chance to discuss a film in detail with others after watching it. So, I started a film club with two friends! We decided not to rent a cinema. Instead, we choose a different location in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which made the atmosphere perfect for the film, and it was fantastic! Some places we use are free because the owners sell snacks during the film, allowing us to keep our prices low. We are happy to cover our costs without making a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets easier, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We can track ticket sales online, so we don’t worry about empty seats anymore! There is still a lot to do, but when people of all ages tell us how much they enjoyed the experience, it feels great. Our website has been very helpful, and we are now connected with other film clubs across the country. We have visited them to see how they operate, but it’s always nice to return to our own club! We also started a blog because we know most people look online for film information instead of reading local reviews. We have tried putting up posters in cafés, but nothing is as effective as word of mouth – people telling their friends about us. The audience loves the special activities we organize with each film; last month, we had a movie quiz that everyone enjoyed."

Text: "Taking photographs was my favorite activity as a child. When I turned 15, I wanted to improve my hobby, so I started a special project: I would take one photograph every day for a year. Many young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea. After a few weeks, I decided to share my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and show my work to others. I was surprised to find that people liked my perspective and style. I enjoyed photographing many different subjects. Then, someone suggested that if my photos had a common theme, my project would be even better. I agreed and began focusing on nature, especially birds and the sky. Most of my photos were in black and white, which was different from what many other young photographers were doing, as they preferred color. This made me doubt my project at times, and I almost gave up. However, I learned to trust my feelings and became more confident in my style. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher, who told me about a national photography competition for my age group. I entered some of my photos just for fun. I will never forget the moment the judges announced that I had won first prize; I was so happy because my project meant a lot to me. It was the first time I realized that my photography might be good enough for a career. Now, I have my own photography studio, and I have never regretted my choice."

Text: "I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try new activities like camping, sailing, and public speaking. In the NYC, you can participate in various activities that help you grow and learn. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, led by adult volunteers called ‘leaders’. When you complete each level, you receive a certificate. 

When I first joined, my leader suggested that I help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was unsure about this because I had joined that same club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other children already had their own groups, so I stopped going after a few weeks. However, I decided to accept the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate. 

Soon, I found myself wanting to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became much more important to me than just getting the certificate. After I completed the challenge, the NYC leader allowed me to continue volunteering at the club because I had formed good relationships with the children. Now, I spend about four hours a week there, and I always look forward to it. 

Because of what I learned at the children’s club, I have decided that after I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who works with children. I had never thought about my future job or youth work before starting at the club. This experience has been my favorite part of the NYC, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I now have several NYC certificates, including one for camping!"

Text: "I was born in Denver, USA, and I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a mountain resort about two hours from Denver. The slope looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try it. I was too young to ask him if I could snowboard, but he loved it and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it seem easy, and eventually, I did well. After that first experience, I quickly grew to love the sport and improved my skills. I began competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but my passion for participating and winning has only grown stronger as I’ve aged, which motivates me to work harder. I like not having a strict plan, and sometimes this works out well, like when I became the first female to score a perfect 100 in a local competition. I didn’t think I would attempt the jumps that earned me that score until I actually started. That achievement boosted my confidence in my abilities. In the summer, I focus on training and studying when there’s no snow. I train every day, but it’s nice not to follow a strict diet like I do in winter. I also spend a lot of time with my friends, which helps me cope with not being able to do what I love. I need to think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life, but I believe it’s important to have another option in case I don’t become a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I’m considering whether becoming a doctor is possible if my active lifestyle allows time for college. I can’t imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can’t do it forever."

Text: "When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had, and I didn’t think about the future. For example, I didn’t know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I thought I should have one too. My parents said I could only get it if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I am grateful to my parents for this because it taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn’t enjoy it much, so my parents suggested I start my own small business. I had seen my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try that. I never thought it would be so easy, as it looked complicated when I watched my mum. My friends thought it sounded boring, but I was excited about it. My mum showed me that I could create something nice at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first pieces of jewellery to my friends and family as soon as I finished making them. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. Even though I was happy they bought them, I needed to be sure they were good enough for other people. The only way to find out was to rent a market stall with my mum. There are many tourists where I live, and they bought a lot of my items to take home. Soon, we started getting calls from all over the country from people wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company with many employees, but we were just two people at a market stall! That’s when I realized it could work, and it was time to take the next step – creating a website. Since then, I’ve made thousands of pounds from my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It has been a lot of fun so far."

Text: 'When Janine Stuart was just 13 years old, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became a bestseller. The book is partly inspired by Janine’s own life. In an interview, Janine explained, “Because of my father’s job, my family moved around a lot, so I learned to make new friends easily. I know what it’s like to be the new student in a class, which helped me write about how the main character, Amelia, adjusts to a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. Since I’m an only child, I had to use my imagination to describe that.” 

Janine began writing her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it felt natural for Janine to spend her time this way. The year before, she had entered a short story competition on a young writers’ website and won first prize. This is why, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they were eager to read it. They loved the book, and a year later, it was available in bookstores. 

One review of Being Amelia notes that, despite the cheerful pictures of teenagers on the cover, the characters face real challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer mentions that even though Janine is still very young and her novel is not very long, she has shown that she is a better writer than many bestselling authors. Janine is still adjusting to her fame: “At first, I would hide when people recognized me in the street, but now it’s fine. I want to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, I just need to spend time with my friends, and I’ll soon have something interesting to write about!”'

Text: "My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. This happened because my father was invited to manage the castle. He works for a group that takes care of historical buildings and keeps them open for visitors. He was excited about this opportunity, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree that he should accept the job. We were worried about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our warm home across the water, and there was no school nearby. However, after we moved, we quickly adapted to island life. The castle is not particularly beautiful, but our apartment there is cozy. In the summer, the island is lively with many visitors, and there are often beach parties. In winter, we mostly see the other families who live on the island, but there are not many teenagers among them, which I had hoped for. The adults help each other with repairs on the island, which can be hard work. 

The biggest change for me was taking a boat every day to my old school. I looked forward to the stormy days when there are big waves, but the ferries do not run then! I also learned that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I miss the last ferry home, which is stressful. So, when my friends come to visit, I always tell them to hurry! However, we often enjoy amazing views, especially when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it is so foggy that you cannot see anything, but then, within hours, it can be bright and sunny again. This still feels incredible, even after living here for a while. Of course, we do experience terrible storms, and I sometimes wonder if the castle is strong enough to withstand them. But then I remind myself that it has stood for centuries and is still here!"

I live in a house in the beautiful countryside of Scotland. I have always loved nature and wild animals. Six years ago, I started a new hobby: birdwatching! I went to the mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural habitat. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to identify different species and find the best spots to see them. It was amazing! After returning home, I joined a local birdwatching club for young people. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I am close to achieving it. During family holidays abroad, I have seen birds from other countries as well. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities so I can add new birds to my list! I have been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America, where I thought I would see my 200th species. I was not too disappointed when it didn’t happen, as I learned that patience is important in this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers found it interesting and commented positively. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I felt nervous just before I walked onto the stage, knowing that the whole school and my friends were watching me. I relaxed only after it was over, and the teachers said I had prepared well and they enjoyed it. I might even do another presentation next year! I feel lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not consider birdwatching, but there are many birds to see, especially in green areas. I believe birdwatching clubs should encourage more young people to take up this hobby. Everyone should connect with nature, no matter their age, and it doesn’t have to be expensive.

Text: "I began playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and soon I became a decent player. My family knew I often got excited about new hobbies and then lost interest, so they probably thought I would do the same with football. But that never happened. I even started dreaming of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and one referee saw that I was a talented player, so he asked the manager of a professional women's club to watch me. After that, she invited me to join her club. I was surprised at first – I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But the manager was impressed, and I began regular training with a big club when I was just 13. After that, I improved a lot. Still, some people doubted I would ever be a star player, which made me a little sad. But my coach encouraged me to be myself and believe in my abilities – he even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches earlier than I expected! I ran harder than ever because I didn’t want to let my teammates down. By chance, I scored the winning goal. Even with the large crowd, I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, my team carried me around the pitch. It was amazing! Since then, I’ve scored many more winning goals! Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and allow them to meet other players from my club. It will show them the professional environment and inspire them to believe they could play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach gave me – there will be good times, but also some challenges. I’ve had very few challenges, though – so I’ve been lucky!"

Text: 'In recent years, a significant change in education in the UK and around the world has been the encouragement for new students to engage in research early in their studies. This change acknowledges that research is not just for famous scholars or scientists, but is a natural way to build knowledge and skills. Research skills are valuable not only for your studies but also for your future jobs, as they help you think critically about the world and your work. 

As a student, you contribute to knowledge. You do not just memorize and repeat information; you create it. Creating knowledge involves asking questions instead of accepting things as they are. You might wonder: Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? These questions are at the heart of research. 

Research can be seen as a range of activities. On one end, there is complex, groundbreaking research done by highly trained experts, which leads to significant changes in knowledge. However, research can also start from simple inquiries that involve careful work and thoughtful questions about various issues and practices. 

Most students have always been researchers in some way. You have likely done research for school projects or answered questions at work since you began your education. You have asked questions that required investigation, whether it was about planning a holiday, growing plants, fixing things at home, training a pet, or finding the right products online. 

In college and higher education, it is expected that you will have a curious mind, identify problems, critically explore information, and create your own understanding to contribute to discussions. Some students may find this challenging because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as fixed, and learning often involves listening to teachers and texts without questioning them. It may feel disrespectful to challenge established knowledge or authority, and you might think you should be told what is important to learn. 

However, in higher education in the UK, US, much of Europe, and Australasia, questioning established knowledge and authorities is encouraged. This process of inquiry and knowledge creation can seem intimidating. Critical thinking is essential in research. The research done by others is valuable for students and professionals, but we must not simply repeat what we read as if it is always true. Instead, we should engage with it, think critically, test ideas, and determine if the information is logical and supported by evidence. We should avoid relying blindly on the facts and information provided by others.'

Text: 'Cities have always been centers of intellectual activity, from the coffee houses of 18th-century London, where people discussed science and politics, to the Left Bank cafés in modern Paris, where artist Pablo Picasso talked about modern art. However, living in a city is not easy. The same London cafés that encouraged discussion also helped spread diseases like cholera; Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. While modern cities can be places of creativity, they can also feel unnatural and overwhelming. Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains, and the findings are concerning. It has long been known that city life can be tiring, but new research shows that living in cities can actually impair our thinking, sometimes significantly. One major factor is the lack of nature, which is surprisingly beneficial for our brains. Studies have shown that hospital patients recover faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even brief views of nature seem to enhance brain function because they provide a mental break from the stress of urban life. This research comes at a time when more people than ever live in cities. Instead of enjoying open spaces, we are packed into concrete environments, surrounded by many strangers. Recent studies indicate that these unnatural surroundings can negatively impact our mental and physical health and change how we think. Think about everything your brain has to manage while walking down a busy street: distracted pedestrians, dangerous crossings that require attention to traffic, and the confusing layout of the city. These seemingly simple tasks can leave us feeling drained because they take advantage of a weakness in our brains. Cities are filled with stimuli, forcing us to constantly shift our focus. This kind of controlled attention—deciding what to ignore—requires energy. The brain is like a powerful computer, but focusing uses a lot of its processing power. In contrast, natural environments do not demand as much mental effort. This concept is known as attention restoration theory, developed by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. It has long been understood that human attention is limited—focusing in the morning makes it harder to concentrate in the afternoon. Kaplan suggested that being in nature could help restore our attention. Natural settings have elements that naturally attract our focus but do not provoke negative feelings, unlike a police siren, for example. In nature, our attention can relax and recharge. Long before scientists studied this, philosophers and landscape architects warned about the effects of city life and sought ways to include nature in urban settings. Urban parks, like Central Park in New York, provide a much-needed escape from city life. A well-designed park can enhance brain function in just a few minutes. While people have tried many methods to boost cognitive performance, from energy drinks to office redesigns, few are as effective as simply taking a walk in nature. Given the many mental challenges caused by city life, one might wonder: Why do cities keep growing? And why do they remain sources of intellectual activity, even in the digital age? Recent research from the Santa Fe Institute shows that the same urban features that can lead to attention and memory problems—the crowded streets and close proximity of people—are also linked to innovation. It is the ‘concentration of social interactions’ that drives urban creativity, according to scientists. Just as the crowded environment of 18th-century London led to new ideas, the crowded nature of 21st-century Cambridge, Massachusetts, supports its role as a hub of technology and creativity. Conversely, less crowded urban areas may produce less innovation over time. The challenge, then, is to find ways to reduce the psychological stress of city life while preserving its unique advantages. Because there will always come a time when someone will say: ‘I’m tired of nature; take me to the city!’"

**Simplified Text:**

Where should we search for the mind? This question may seem strange because we usually think that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain imaging techniques that support this idea. However, I believe there is no strong reason to limit the study of the mind to just the brain or body. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, showing that objects, as well as our brain cells, play a role in how we think. 

From an archaeological perspective, it is clear that tools, jewelry, carvings, clay tokens, and writing systems have significantly influenced human evolution and the development of our minds. Therefore, I propose that what exists outside our heads may also be part of our minds. It is understandable that scientists often connect the mind with the brain because much of what we know about the mind comes from studying people without their usual surroundings. This is practical for neuroscientists, especially when using brain scanners. However, this focus can overlook the fact that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. 

I do not intend to deny the importance of the brain in thinking, but I want to emphasize that the mind is more than just the brain. It is more useful to consider the idea that human intelligence extends beyond our bodies into culture and the physical world. This is where my new theory, called Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes into play. MET explores how objects can become extensions of our thinking or be integrated into our bodies. For example, when we create numbers and symbols from clay or use a stone to make a tool, we are engaging with materials in a cognitive way. 

MET also looks at how these interactions have changed since ancient times and what these changes mean for our thinking. This perspective provides new insights into what minds are and how they are shaped by the things around us. Consider a blind person using a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The connection between the blind person and the stick illustrates how minds and objects can be seen as interconnected. It also shows the flexibility of the human mind: by using the stick, the blind person transforms touch into a form of sight, and the stick itself plays an important role. 

The sensation felt at the tip of the stick connects the person to the environment, and the brain treats the stick as part of the body. The blind person’s stick reminds us that human intelligence can adapt and change significantly by incorporating new technologies. I view the human mind as an ongoing project that is always evolving. 

It is essential to remember that, regardless of what form the ‘stick’ has taken throughout human history—whether it is a simple stone tool or a modern smartphone—its main purpose is to serve as a connection rather than a limit. Through this ‘stick’, humans explore, learn, and understand their surroundings, while also finding new paths forward. This is different from how monkeys use sticks to get food. For humans, ‘sticks’ are tools for satisfying our curiosity. 

This unique human ability to engage with material culture explains why we create things more than any other species, and how these creations, in turn, shape our minds. I call this concept metaplasticity—our minds are flexible and develop as they interact with the material world. I want to reintroduce the importance of material objects into our understanding of cognition. MET provides a new way to see how various forms of material culture, from ancient tools to modern devices, have influenced and transformed who we are and how we think. While the idea of technology changing our minds may sound futuristic, it is important to realize that humans have been using such technology since our earliest days.

Text: 'Few inventions have changed civilization as much as photography. This is especially true in the United States, where photography quickly became part of culture at all levels – practical, scientific, industrial, and aesthetic, as well as in entertainment. Historians argue that photography is one of the greatest contributions of the US to the visual arts. This claim reflects the idea that photography has become central to US intellectual and artistic discussions, and to understand its impact, we must look at its origins in the mid-19th century.

Why was photography so appealing? First, its mechanical process matched a growing interest in technology, part of a national mindset that embraced change. Just as steam power, railroads, and electricity made communication and travel easier, photography brought the wonders of the world into homes with stunning immediacy. Second, the camera became the preferred tool for representing the self, allowing individuals to create public images in a society where identities were constantly formed and reformed. Third, the camera played a significant role in creating and preserving family memories, even if those memories were somewhat idealized. Finally, the realism of photographs aligned with a broader artistic trend towards realism in US art.

Every photograph draws attention to something specific, showing what the photographer wants us to see. The fact that photographs are made by machines, unlike drawings, gives them a unique quality: they are records of events, people, and things, representing what was in front of the camera and embodying a certain objectivity. However, since each photograph is taken by an individual, it also carries a personal perspective. We might look at a photograph and think we understand its meaning, leading to the idea that photography is a 'universal language.' Yet, the meaning of a photograph is more complex. Few subjects convey their own meaning, and every image comes with context that shapes our understanding, such as captions in newspapers or layouts in magazines.

To understand a photograph historically, we must consider its purpose and role within its cultural context: Why did the photographer take the image? How was it first viewed? Additionally, the same image can be interpreted differently depending on where and when it is seen. While the importance of the camera to artists was not widely recognized for a long time, it is now clear. In recent decades, starting with artist Andy Warhol’s use of photographs in his work, artists have been integrating photography in various ways. In summary, photographic vision has become an essential part of painting and our understanding of representation before the invention of the camera.'

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and physician, defined psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still relevant today. We all have a mental life, which gives us some understanding of what this means. Although we can study mental life in animals like rats and monkeys, it remains a complex concept. James focused on human psychology, which he believed included basic elements: thoughts, feelings, the physical world, and a way of knowing about these elements. Our knowledge is mostly personal and comes from our own experiences, which may or may not align with scientific facts.

This personal understanding can lead us to make judgments about psychological issues based on our own experiences. We often act as amateur psychologists when we share opinions on complex topics, such as whether brainwashing is effective or why people behave in certain ways. Problems arise when two people interpret situations differently. Formal psychology aims to provide methods to determine which explanations are most likely correct in various situations. Psychologists help us differentiate between subjective thoughts, which can be biased, and objective facts.

While psychology studies the mind and brain, psychologists do not yet fully understand how the brain works in relation to our emotions and behaviors. It is often difficult to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by observing behavior and forming hypotheses about what happens inside us. A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective, but the mind's workings are not directly observable. Instead, they must be inferred from behavior, much like solving a crossword puzzle by interpreting clues.

Psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and modify the processes it studies. Achieving these goals helps us understand our experiences and apply findings to real-life situations. Psychological research has been beneficial in various fields, such as improving reading methods for children, designing safer machine controls, and helping people express their feelings to alleviate emotional distress.

Although psychological questions have been discussed for centuries, scientific investigation began only in the last 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection, or self-reflection, to answer psychological questions. They aimed to identify mental structures, which remains important today. However, introspection has limitations, as noted by Sir Francis Galton, who said it only reveals a small part of the brain's automatic functions. William James compared introspection to trying to see how darkness looks by turning up the gas quickly. Therefore, modern psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of behavior rather than solely on personal reflections.

In a storehouse located in a typical business park in Michigan, USA, there exists a unique collection known as the Museum of Failed Products. This museum, owned by a company called GfK, showcases items that were taken off the market because they did not sell well, such as A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola. The museum's owner, Carol Sherry, believes that each product tells a story about the designers, marketers, and salespeople involved.

Interestingly, the museum operates as a successful business, even though many companies do not keep records of their failed products. Executives visit the museum, showing how uncommon it is for businesses to reflect on their failures. The museum was started by Robert McMath, who initially wanted to create a reference library of consumer products, not specifically failed ones. He began collecting new items in the 1960s, not realizing that most products fail. As a result, his collection ended up being mostly unsuccessful products.

Today’s optimistic culture may contribute to the products found in the museum. Many products likely went through meetings where no one recognized their potential failure. Even if they did, marketers might invest more money into failing products to save face. There is often little effort to understand why these products failed, and people involved may choose to forget about it.

This tendency to focus on positivity is also seen in the self-help industry, where the idea of "positive visualization" is popular. This concept suggests that imagining positive outcomes can lead to better results. Neuroscientist Tali Sharot has found evidence that our brains may be wired to see the chances of success as higher than they actually are. Her research indicates that well-adjusted individuals often have an overly optimistic view of their ability to influence events compared to those who are depressed.

However, psychologist Gabriele Oettingen and her team have studied the effectiveness of positive thinking. Their findings show that spending time imagining successful outcomes can actually reduce people's motivation to achieve their goals. For instance, people who were encouraged to visualize a productive week at work ended up accomplishing less.

Psychologist Carol Dweck explains that our views on failure are shaped by our beliefs about ability. Those with a "fixed mindset" believe that ability is something you are born with, while those with a "growth mindset" think that ability can develop through effort and challenges. People with a fixed mindset often find failure very distressing, seeing it as proof that they are not capable. In contrast, those with a growth mindset view failure as a sign that they are pushing their limits. Dweck compares this to weight training, where muscles grow stronger by being challenged. Ultimately, having a growth mindset leads to a more positive outlook, regardless of success.

Text: 'It is well-known that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But why is this the case? Many people think they understand it, but the world of professional sports is changing quickly, and what we once accepted as true is now being questioned. Two main factors are challenging the traditional view of home advantage: science and money. Sports scientists are exploring what helps players perform their best, leading to many theories about home advantage. At the same time, those who invest in sports want to know why home advantage is still important. If players are paid well, shouldn’t they feel comfortable playing anywhere?

This raises questions for fans. For example, would it matter if Manchester United played some home games in the Far East to reach their fans there? It would matter to British fans, who believe their team needs their support and loyalty. This belief may lead them to confuse cause and effect. When a team plays well, the home crowd cheers loudly, and sometimes this leads to a goal. Fans often remember the times they cheered and a goal was scored, forgetting the many times their cheers did not lead to success.

However, there is one common belief among fans that scientific evidence supports. Home fans not only cheer for their team but also direct their energy towards the referee. In a well-known study, referees watched a match with crowd noise and another version without sound. The referees who heard the crowd were less likely to call fouls against the home team compared to those who watched in silence. Interestingly, the crowd noise did not make them more likely to call fouls against the away team. The researchers concluded that referees try to avoid the stress of making calls that would upset the home crowd.

Recent studies show that home advantage has decreased in all major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the early years of the Football League in the 1890s, home teams won about 70% of the points, while today they win about 60%. One reason for this change could be travel. In the past, travel was difficult, but now players travel in great comfort, and if their hotel is not satisfactory, the club will find them a better one. Local conditions used to vary greatly, but now top stadiums are becoming more similar in their efficiency.

Despite these explanations, none fully account for the data. The mystery remains as to why home advantage varies by sport. Basketball has the greatest home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. One reason could be that home advantage is more about teamwork, and baseball focuses more on individual matchups between the batter and pitcher. Team sports require coordination among teammates. In basketball, success depends on all players working together, which builds confidence when playing at home, regardless of the playing conditions.

Another possibility relates to a more primal aspect of sports. Researchers found that players’ testosterone levels were normal before training and away games, but increased by up to 67% before home games. This territorial instinct may connect to a basic urge to protect their home ground, as seen in recent Rugby World Cup matches. In two notable games, underdog teams won at home against stronger opponents, showing determination and a refusal to be intimidated—characteristics of home advantage. As one referee put it, ‘It’s the law of the jungle out there.’'

Text: "‘The more I practice, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player about fifty years ago. This saying is popular among many dedicated athletes and their coaches. The reason is clear. First, there is debate about who originally said it, with many other golfers from that time being suggested. Second, the meaning is not straightforward. Player did not mean luck in a literal sense; he was being ironic. His true message was: ‘The more I practice, the better I get.’ But there is a limit to this idea. The question of where that limit is, or if it even exists, relates to the nature-nurture debate – whether talent is something we are born with or something we develop through practice. However, it is misleading to call it a debate, as it suggests a fair balance. In reality, the idea that practice is more important than natural talent has gained much support. This view is largely based on the work of psychologist Anders Ericsson, who proposed that anyone can become an expert in any field with 10,000 hours of practice. His theory has inspired popular books like Malcolm Gladwell’s Outliers, Talent Is Overrated, and Bounce: The Myth of Talent and the Power of Practice. These books generally agree that practice is the most important factor, suggesting that ‘10,000 hours is both necessary and sufficient to make anyone an expert in anything.’ 

However, as Epstein discusses in his engaging book, this is often not the case. He points out a significant flaw in much research on excellence: it usually focuses only on successful individuals. He asks if there are better ways to understand why some people have certain abilities while others do not, and how to separate innate traits from those shaped by environment, support, opportunity, and determination. Epstein travels worldwide, from Kenya to Sweden, and from the Caribbean to the Arctic, even exploring non-human examples. In Alaska, he discovers that the key to success in the toughest sled dog race may be the drive and desire of the husky dogs, suggesting a link between genetics and traits we think are voluntary. This raises the question: can commitment and determination be chosen, or are they influenced by genetics? 

Epstein highlights the complexity of this topic. He differentiates between hardware (nature) and software (nurture), agreeing that both are essential for elite athletes. He does not downplay the importance of training or environment. For instance, he suggests that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have become a good basketball player instead of the fastest man in history. However, he also examines cases where genetics play a crucial role that cannot be overlooked. He addresses the important issues of race and gender, asking: ‘If only practice hours matter, why do we separate men and women in sports?’ Sometimes, the best questions are the most obvious."

A recent international report shows that many children in wealthy countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks a simple question: why are today’s children so unhappy? In her new book, Kith, Griffiths explains that these children spend too much time indoors, stuck in front of screens, and have lost touch with nature – the woods, mountains, rivers, and streams. She believes this is the main issue. This idea connects with other discussions about childhood today. A follow-up study interviewed children to understand their feelings better. The children did not express a desire for new technology; many said they would be happier if they could just go outside more. Many adults over 40 often reminisce about their own childhoods, recalling how they spent long summer days exploring, swimming, or building forts. They believe this was healthier than the protected lives of today’s children. However, they often forget that they are the ones who created these protective environments for their kids, avoiding risks like building forts in old sheds.

Griffiths’ book contains strong arguments. She discusses the fear parents have about dangers in the outside world and how this fear leads to more child-focused consumerism. Parents wanting to keep their children safe often buy toys and gadgets to entertain them at home. She also criticizes trends like prescribing medication for restless children or requiring kids to wear goggles during playground games. While I am unsure how common these rules are, Griffiths expresses her frustration with passion, discussing various aspects of childhood freedoms and restrictions, from fairy tales to school rules.

Although her arguments are appealing, Griffiths sometimes goes too far. She has a good idea but does not know when to stop, ignoring important counter-arguments. At one point, she even compares the treatment of children today to a subtle form of racism, which seems extreme. Griffiths tends to have a romantic view of children. While she acknowledges that children can be mischievous, she mostly presents an idealized view of them that may not match reality. She suggests that children should have the freedom to explore and take risks, believing they need to experience some danger to learn how to manage it. She writes, “Children need accidents,” meaning small accidents that help them avoid bigger ones later. However, she does not explain how to create these small accidents. Additionally, not all children may want the adventurous life Griffiths admires. What about the shy, cautious children who prefer to stay at home? Perhaps the real issue is that society often forces all children into the same mold, whether by keeping them indoors or pushing them outside.

I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, which means I have studied a lot. I am good at solving problems in my work and life, but this skill is not just from my education. Many life problems cannot be solved with complicated formulas or memorized answers learned in school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity that come from life experiences. For children, these experiences often happen through play. 

My recent research focuses on the importance of play for children's development. All young mammals, including humans, play, and those who have the most to learn tend to play the most. Carnivores play more than herbivores because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates play more than other mammals because they rely more on learning than on instinct. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they are allowed to. 

Play is a natural way for both adults and mammals to learn. The most important skills children need to live happy and productive lives cannot be taught in school. These skills are learned and practiced through play. They include thinking creatively, getting along with others, cooperating, and controlling emotions. Creativity is essential for success in today’s world. We no longer need people who just follow instructions or perform routine calculations. We need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems. If we can encourage creative thinkers, we will have a strong workforce. 

Creative minds are playful minds. Adults we call geniuses are those who keep and develop their childlike creativity throughout their lives. Albert Einstein said that school almost destroyed his interest in math and physics, but he regained it after leaving school. He described his innovative work as "combinatorial play." He imagined chasing a sunbeam and thought about what that would mean. 

We cannot teach creativity, but we can stifle it through schooling that focuses on fixed questions rather than children’s own inquiries. More importantly, children need to learn to get along with others, care for them, and cooperate. Children naturally want to play with others, and through play, they learn social skills, fairness, and morality, which are essential for their future. 

Play is voluntary, meaning players can choose to stop. If they cannot stop, it is not play. Players understand that to keep the game enjoyable, they must make others happy. This ability to quit makes play a very democratic activity. 

However, school has become more demanding: breaks are shorter, homework is more, and there is more pressure for high grades. Outside of school, adult-led sports have taken the place of spontaneous games. Supervised "play dates" have replaced unsupervised play, and adults often feel they must intervene instead of letting children solve their own problems. 

These changes have happened slowly but have had a significant impact. They are caused by various social factors, including parents' fears, warnings from experts about dangers, less connected neighborhoods, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. 

Our children do not need more school; they need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must change the negative trend of the past fifty years. We must give childhood back to children. They should be allowed to follow their natural desire to play and explore, so they can grow into strong adults ready for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, more young people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Websites like Twitter and LinkedIn allow direct contact with potential employers, which is a modern way to get noticed compared to the old method of standing outside an office with a sign saying "hire me." However, this increased access also means there is a higher risk of making mistakes. 

For example, a young job seeker in the US reached out to a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn, hoping to connect with her influential contacts. The executive was offended by the idea of sharing her hard-earned connections with a stranger and not only rejected his request but also sent a sarcastic message that went viral online. Many people were shocked by her response, and she likely regrets her tone, if not her message. However, if this incident encourages young people to think more carefully about their professional use of social media, it may have been beneficial. 

Social media can be a risky tool for job seekers who do not know how to use it properly, and many are making mistakes. Ironically, platforms like Facebook and Twitter have been central to the social lives of young people for years. In the past, social media was a way to escape from parents and teachers, a place to impress others and create a different identity. You could have long conversations online and then ignore those people in real life. 

When using social media for professional networking, the skills learned as teenagers may not apply. Many young people still act as if being bold and confident is appropriate, but this can backfire. Just because many people liked your posts on Facebook does not mean you will impress employers on LinkedIn. It is important to understand that the rules of social networking have changed, and young people must meet employers' expectations to succeed in the job market.

One common complaint from employers is that young job seekers often come across as too familiar or arrogant in their messages. This reinforces the stereotype of young people as an "entitled generation." In reality, many are struggling to find jobs, which is why they turn to social media. This perception of arrogance can hurt their chances, even if they have the skills and motivation to be valuable employees.

So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly introduce yourself and explain what you can offer them, such as doing research or helping in another way. This approach increases your chances of receiving a positive response. Avoid sending generic messages, and keep your tone respectful to leave a good impression. Remember, social media can be a powerful tool for making connections, but it requires careful use to avoid negative outcomes.

Text: "Anyone who claims they can accurately predict the future of newspapers is either lying or mistaken. The numbers show that newspapers are struggling. Since 2000, the circulation of most UK national daily newspapers has dropped by one-third to one-half. The Pew Research Centre in the USA reports that newspapers are now the main source of news for only 26% of US citizens, down from 45% in 2001. Many people confidently predict that the last printed newspaper will disappear within 15 years. However, history shows that old forms of media often survive. In 1835, a journalist in New York claimed that books and theatre were finished and that newspapers would become the most important source of news. Yet, theatre has survived alongside newspapers, cinema, and television. Radio has thrived even in the age of TV, and cinema has continued to do well against videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records have made a comeback, with online sales increasing by 745% since 2008. 

Newspapers were once a new form of media, but it took centuries for them to become the main source of news. This was not only because it became practical and affordable to produce timely news for a large audience in the mid-19th century, thanks to the steam press, railways, and telegraphs. It was also due to the idea that everything around us is always changing, and we need regular updates – a concept that was foreign in medieval times. Our ancestors saw life as cyclical, marked only by the changing seasons and unpredictable disasters like famine or disease. 

Before the 19th century, journalism as a profession was not well established, and there was no clear need for people to receive news regularly. In some ways, the regular publication of newspapers can be a limitation. Online news allows readers to access information based on their own interests and the urgency of events. Advanced search engines and algorithms help us customize the news we receive. When significant news breaks, online news sources can provide updates almost instantly. There are no space limits that restrict storytelling or analysis, and readers can often access full documents or events mentioned in news articles. This is very different from the constraints of newspaper publishing.

However, many news providers do not seem to recognize the potential of the internet to enhance understanding. Instead, the focus is often on being the first to report news, increasing reader comments, and creating excitement, which can lead to confusion. In medieval times, news was often shared in busy marketplaces or taverns, where truth competed with rumors and misunderstandings. In some ways, we seem to be returning to that environment. Newspapers have not always been effective at explaining how the world works. They may be facing extinction, or perhaps, as the internet adds to our feeling of living in a chaotic world, newspapers will find a way to help us gain wisdom and understanding."

Text: "If humans truly belonged under the moon and stars, we would walk in the dark happily, seeing the midnight world as clearly as many night animals do. However, we are daytime creatures, with eyes made for sunlight.
